courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Perspectives in Economics
courses.description:
(UGEC1511 is double-coded with ECON1010.)

This is an introduction to the nature of the economic problem and how society and man deal with the economic problem. It will cover resource allocation and the concept of economic efficiency, product and factor markets, macroeconomic indicators and the nature of macroeconomic problems, and macroeconomic policy. Economic concepts and theories will be applied to various social and economic issues such as marriage, crime and government policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
ECON1010 is double-coded with UGEC1511. 
Not for students who have taken UGEC1511, ECON2011, DOTE1030, DOTE1040, DSME1030 or DSME1040.
courses.learning_outcomes:
It is expected that students will:

- acquire problem solving skills to think like an economist.

- master a set of concepts that will help them think more coherently and consistently about a wide range of problems

- be able to use these skills in their everyday lives as consumers, savers, entrepreneurs, investors, workers, citizens and participants in a global economy.
courses.course_syllabus:
Perspectives in Economics will introduce the fundamental concepts of economic and issues in economic research, covering both micro and macro economics. The course attempts to illustrate the importance and beauty of economics via a non-technical approach, using only elementary mathematics and graphs for expositions. Topics will include concepts of rationality, opportunity cost analysis, the functioning of supply and demand, the role of government and fiscal policy, the banking system and monetary policy, pricing, and some topics pertaining to crime, marriage and international trade. Students in this course will learn how to apply the fundamental economic principles to almost every aspect of their life.

WeekTopic

1Rationality, What, When, How, Whom

2Demand and Supply Theory

3Demand and Supply Application: Marriage

4Demand and Supply Application: Crime

5Demand and Supply Application: Rent Control

6Measuring Economic Performance: National Income Accounting

7Measuring Economic Performance: Inflation and Unemployment

8Money Creation and Banking System

9Monetary and Fiscal Policy

10Trade and WTO

11Contribution by Nobel Laureates

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Mathematical Methods in Economics I
courses.description: This course introduces basic mathematical tools that are indispensable in modern economics. Topics include set, matrix, exponential and logarithmic functions, single-variable differentiation and optimization. Economic applications are also covered, including equilibrium analysis, comparative statics, and dynamic analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken, or are currently taking, any MATH course at or above 1000-level or ENGG2011, ENGG2012, ENGG2013, ENGG2014, ENGG2015, ENGG2018, or MAEG4070.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand and apply basic relevant mathematical concepts, tools, and techniques to analyze simple economic issues.

2. Learn the basic principles and skills which will be needed for optimization analysis in ECON1111 and other upper level courses in Economics.

1. 理解及運用基本的相關數學概念、工具和技術，分析簡單的經濟問題。

2. 學習適用於優化分析之基本原理和技能，為ECON1111和其他較高級的經濟學課程作準備。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Functions and Equilibrium Analysis

2. Set Theory

3. Linear Models and Matrix Algebra –Determinant and Inverse

4. Limit and Single- variable Differentiation

5. Unconstrained Optimization – First-order condition and Second-order condition

6. Exponential and Logarithmic Functions

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Mathematical Methods in Economics II
courses.description: This course introduces basic mathematical tools that are indispensable in modern economics. Topics include integration, partial differentiation, implicit function method, optimization for multiple variable functions, and Lagrangian multiplier. Economic applications are also covered, including equilibrium analysis, comparative statics, profit maximization, consumer demand, and dynamic analysis. Students should have knowledge of elementary differential and integral calculus, and are advised to take ECON1101 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken, or are currently taking ENGG2011, ENGG2012, ENGG2013, ENGG2014, ENGG2015, ENGG2018, MAEG4070, or MATH2010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- be able to perform basic calculations involving differentiation for multiple variable functions (partial and total derivatives), implicit function method, unconstrained optimization for multiple variable functions (1st and 2nd order conditions) and Lagrangian method.

- know economic examples of these concepts and tools.

- 運用基本的計算包括多變量函數（偏及全微分） 、隱函數方法、多變量函數無約束最優化方法（一階條件與二階條件) 及拉格朗日乘數。

- 運用所介紹的概念和工具明白經濟學中一些例子。
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces basic mathematical tools that are indispensable in modern economics. Topics include integration, partial differentiation, implicit function method, optimization for multiple variable functions, and Lagrangian multiplier. Economic applications are also covered, including equilibrium analysis, comparative statics, profit maximization, consumer demand, and dynamic analysis.

本科介紹經濟學中常用之數學方法，內容包括：積分學、偏微分、隱函數方法、多變量函數之最優化方法及拉格朗日乘數。本科亦討論這些數學方法在經濟學中的應用，包括均衡分析，比較靜態分析、利潤極大化，消費者需求、及動態分析。

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics and Society
courses.description: An aim of economics is to study the interaction of individuals’ decisions and how markets solve the problems of resource allocation. This course uses economics to study certain pressing problems that society faces today. Topics include energy resource, global warming, environmental protection, poverty, education, health care, and discrimination. In the process of studying these problems, students get some exposure to economics and at the same time, come to understand society more deeply. (Advisory: This course is not for ECON Majors and Minors.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) understand basic concepts used in economics

2) know how the market works

3) understand the economic nature of social problems

4) apply economics to study environmental problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Pareto efficiency and Kaldor-Hicks efficiency

2) How markets work

3) Consumer and producer surpluses and GDP

4) The problem of social cost

5) The economic analysis of law

6) Trade and environment

7) Economics and global warming

8) Economics and ocean fishes

9) Poverty and other social problems

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course mainly explores the way contemporary economists analyse current social problems/issues. Through reading about and discussing current issues as well as the related works of contemporary economists, important economic theories will be highlighted and major current issues will be exposed. The aim of this course is to provide students with a broad and intuitive overview of economic theories and applied concepts. (Advisory: This course is not for ECON Majors and Minors.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
students shall

- have a basic exposure to some fundamental economic concepts.

- be able to develop critical opinions to assess misconceptions of current economic policies or key issues around the world.

- be able to infuse economic thinking into their daily lives and decisions.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Current Hong Kong Economic Issues
courses.description: This course introduces students with no economics background to various aspects of the Hong Kong economy, such as trade, industries, logistics, housing and real estate, banking and finance, the monetary system and linked exchange rate, public finance, employment, inflation, income distribution and the China-Hong Kong economic relationship. Well-known experts from the financial sector and governmental organizations will be invited to analyse the latest information and discuss some of the above economic issues and development.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2311 or ECON3380 or UGEC1825.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Have a sense of the development of Hong Kong economy.

2. Understand important economic concepts and their application to analyse major economic issues and policies.

3. Critically evaluate selected Hong Kong economic problems.

4. Improve ability to interpret Hong Kong economic data.

1. 具備對香港經濟發展的觸覺。

2. 理解及應用重要經濟概念來分析其重大經濟議題和政策。

3. 深入評論特定的香港經濟問題。

4. 提升解讀香港經濟數據的能力。
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Hong Kong Development - Composition of GDP/GNP and price indexes, Economic performance, real estate market, the post-1997 slowdown, structural changes and recent development.
2. The International Transactions - The overall international balance of payments (BOP) account, Hong Kong’s BOP positions, development of transport and logistics.
3. Price Adjustment and Labour Employment - Labour productivity, cyclical and structural unemployment.
4. The Public Finance Setting - The basic taxation principles and budgetary policy stance, economic efficiency and income disparity
5. Banking and Finance - Hong Kong monetary system, the monetary rule of the linked exchange rate (LER), the role of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the importance of international financial centre.
6. Integration with the Mainland – CEPA.

1. 香港的發展 - 國內生產總值 / 國民生產總值和物價指數的構成，經濟表現，房地產市場，九七回歸後之經濟放緩，經濟結構轉型及最新發展。
2. 國際貿易 - 整體國際收支平衡帳戶，香港的國際收支狀況，運輸物流的發展。
3. 價格調整和勞工就業 - 勞動生產力，週期性和結構性失業。
4. 公共財政的背景 - 稅務基本原則和財政預算政策的立場，經濟效率和所得分配差距。
5. 銀行與金融 - 香港貨幣制度，聯繫匯率的運作準則，香港金融管理局的角色，國際金融中心之重要性。
6. 香港與內地經濟融合 - 《內地與香港更緊密經貿關係安排》。

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Basic Banking and Finance
courses.description:
(UGEC1560 is double-coded with ECON1420.)

This course is an overview of the institutional and practical aspects of the banking and financial sectors of the economy, with emphasis on how the two sectors impact on the economic well being of workers, consumers, and investors. This course is designed for students with no previous knowledge or training in economics. Topics to be discussed include: interest rate determination, operation and management of the banking system, banking policy and supervision, interbank market and liquidity, money supply, exchange rate systems and linked exchange rate, investment returns, risk diversification and portfolio choice, stock market movement, initial public offering and derivatives, financial ethics, international debt crisis, and their relationships with consumer prices, trade, investment, unemployment and the level of economic activity.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
ECON1420 is double-coded with UGEC1560.
Not for students who have taken UGEC1560, ECON3410, ECON3420, ECON3520 or GESC2410.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the basic operation of the banking system and financial markets and the importance of ethics and integrity.
2. Apply and interpret the basics of asset price valuation and method to financial instruments such as equity, debt, and derivatives.
3. Apply relevant concepts, tools, and techniques to analyze some major financial and banking activities and issues and to understand their impacts of on people’s livelihood.
4. Improve ability to interpret financial data.

1. 了解銀行體系和金融市場的基本運作及誠信和道德操守之重要。
2. 運用和解釋股票、債券、衍生金融工具等證券資產價格評價和證券估值技巧。
3. 運用相關概念，工具和技巧來分析一些重大的金融及銀行活動和議題，及了解其對人民生活的影響。
4. 提高閱讀和理解財務數據資料的能力。

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: A Guide to Learning Economics
courses.description:
This course is designed for economic majors in their first year of study. The principal aim is to help students plan their curricula, including the academic and experiential components. It comprises three parts:

1. Lectures that introduce the structure of the programme (outcome statement, study pattern of required and elective courses, concentration areas), experiential learning opportunities (mentorship and internship programmes), and exchange opportunities (choice of host institutions and transfer of credits). Senior students may also be asked to share their experiences in mentorship, internship, and exchange.

2. Workshops on academic writing with emphasis on academic honesty. Topics include plagiarism, proper use of source materials, and citation styles. Each student will be asked to write and submit a summary of a collection of articles on a current topic in economics. Feedbacks will be given in a timely manner so that students can correct their errors and resubmit their work. A series of revisions and submissions will finally lead to academically acceptable articles – writings with clear logic, proper use of source materials, and proper citation style.

3. Sessions on presentation skills and interview skills. These include in-class debate sessions, group interview practices and cover-letter workshops.

(Advisory: Course designed for students in their first year of major study in ECON. Capacity limited. Priority given to ECON major students.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, the student will be able to:
1. understand the rationale and structure of the economics programme,
2. plan a curriculum that best suits his/her interest,
3. write economic articles of acceptable academic style,
4. find economic data and articles,
5. critique current issues from the economic perspective,
6. present themselves in a professional manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
The following list of topics are included:
1. The structure of the economics major programme
2. Choice of double majors and minors
3. Experiential learning and exchange opportunities
4. Designing a personal curriculum
5. Academic honesty and proper citation
6. Writing and presenting an academically acceptable article in economics
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Formal course evaluation at end of course.
Feedbacks from students in annual departmental retreat.
Feedbacks from visiting committee and programme review.
courses.required_readings:
Depends on chosen topics, which are of current interest.
To be prescribed in the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings: To be prescribed in the course outline.

courses.title: Basic Microeconomics
courses.description: This course covers basic concepts in microeconomic theory. Major topics include: consumer preference and decision-making, demand theory and applications, theory of the firm, perfect competition in partial equilibrium, monopoly, oligopoly, basic game theory, general competitive equilibrium, welfare economics and market failure.

2. able to creatively apply these theories to understand real-world economic issues.

3. learn how to use demand-supply model, indifference curve/budget line, and the theory of firm in their analysis of policy issues or other real-world issues.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Guided Study in Current Economic Problems I
courses.description:
The student-oriented method of teaching will be applied to the analysis and discussion of economic problems. The course consists of two parts. The first part covers essential skills in research, report writing and presentation. In the second part of the course, students are required to search and discuss articles on current economic problems under the intensive guidance of a teacher. The requirements include the writing of reports, presentation of papers and participation in class discussion.
(Advisory: Course designed for students in their second year of major study in ECON. Capacity limited. Priority given to ECON major students.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
- gain basic knowledge in the design of an appropriate research project
- improve public speaking and overall writing abilities

4. Understand the functioning of fixed and flexible exchange rate regimes.

5. Understand the theoretical and practical limitation of central bank independence.

courses.description: This course studies the basic econometric theory and the application of econometric methods to actual economic data. The emphasis is on explaining basic ideas behind formulas and rules. Topics covered are: basic concepts of statistical inference; estimation and inference for the general linear statistical model; stochastic regressors; heteroscedasticity; disturbance related sets of regression equations; multicollinearity; autocorrelation; and specification, identification and estimation of simultaneous equation models. Students are advised to take ECON2121 before taking this course.

2. Explain how the Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) estimates are obtained

3. Execute regressions using a statistical software like STATA

4. Report and interpret the OLS regression results

5. Apply algebraic properties of the OLS estimates

6. Understand statistical properties of the OLS estimators

7. Explain consequences of the omitted variables in regression models

8. Understand consequences of the violations on the OLS assumptions

9. Test hypotheses about parameters and linear restrictions

10. Conduct policy analysis with two or more time periods

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Mathematical Methods in Economics III
courses.description: This course discusses important mathematical tools that are essential for economic theory and applied economics. Topics include optimization theory, Lagrangian multiplier, differential equations, and difference equations. Economic applications include comparative statics, utility maximization, profit maximization, and dynamic models with continuous and discrete time. Students are advised to take ECON1101 and 1111 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To be familiar with important mathematical tools that are essential for economic theory and applied economics. 2. Improve problem-solving skills.
3. To be able to characterize an economic model analytically.
4. To have a roadmap of mathematical skills needed for economics.
5. To gain confidence to go back and forth between economics and mathematics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Static optimization theory
2. Comparative statics and implicit function theorem
3. Concave and convex functions
4. Homogenous and homothetic functions
5. Differential equations and difference equations.
6. Dynamic optimization—continuous time.
7. Dynamic optimization—discrete time.
8. Fundamental topology and basics of real analysis

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Game Theory
courses.description: The course will introduce the basic tools of game theoretic analysis and their applications in economics. It will cover basic equilibrium concepts (Nash equilibrium, subgame perfect equilibrium) in strategic and extensive form games, Bayesian games, repeated games, and evolutionary games. Applications will include strategic voting, auction design and bargaining. Students are advised to take ECON1101, 1111, 2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand important solution concepts in game theory.

2. Gain insights on strategic interactions in social and economic contexts.

3. Obtain basic skills on game theoretic modeling and analysis.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Strategic Games: Nash equilibrium in pure and mixed strategies, dominance, rationalizability

2. Extensive Games with Perfect Information: backward induction, subgame perfect equilibrium

3. Bayesian Games: Bayesian games, Bayesian Nash equilibrium, public good provision, auction

4. Extensive Games with Imperfect Information: beliefs, sequential rationality, weak perfect Bayesian equilibrium, sequential equilibrium, signaling games

5. Repeated Games: finitely vs. infinitely repeated games, repeated prisoners’ dilemma, folk theorems

courses.description: This is an introductory course on the economic approach to the study of the state and the economy. Topics include: social choice, collective action, voting and elections, bureaucracy, constitution, legal process, institutional change and international political economy. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the models, empirical methodology, and substantive findings in political economics.

2. Acquire the basic tools in political economics for theoretical and empirical work.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics of Transition
courses.description: This course applies simple economic analysis to the study of transitional economies, including countries in Eastern Europe, former Soviet Union and China. Emphasis will be on the study of economic system and firm from the perspective of economic organization. Topics include: historical review and reasons for reform, coordination and incentives, reform strategies (big bang versus gradualism), macroeconomic stabilization and price liberalization, capital market and financial reform, ownership, property rights and privatization, restructuring and management of state-owned enterprises, entrepreneur and evolution of private firms, foreign trade, income distribution and social security, and comparison of reform experience in Eastern Europe and in China. Students should have elementary knowledge of microeconomics and macroeconomics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the basic elements and rise and fall of a socialist, centrally planned economy from the perspective of comparative economic systems.

2. Understand different strategies adopted by various transitional economies to establish market institutions.

3. Understand the process of transition from a socialist, centrally planned economy to a capitalist mixed market economy.

4. Understand some major areas of economic system transition and restructurings that include the ownership reforms, the power and the limit of market forces, the necessities and difficulties in establishing market-supporting institutions, and the social and political aspects of economic transition.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic Elements of a Socialist, Centrally Planned Economy

2. The Rise and Performance of the Socialist Centrally Planned Economies

3. The End of the Socialist Planned Economies and Transition Strategies

4. The Chinese Way of Economic Transition

5. Changes in Resource Allocation: Price Liberalization

6. Government Collapse and Economic Performance

7. Privatization Strategies and Performance

8. Understanding State Ownership from Transitional Experiences

9. Corporate Governance in Transition Economies

10. Political Reforms and Economic Transition

11. Lessons from Economic Transition

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Chinese Economy: Heritage and Change
courses.description: An overview of the transformation of China’s economy from the Han dynasty to the 20th century and its relationship with the rest of the world. The course emphasizes an analysis of the historical development of the Chinese economy in the context of global socioeconomic changes. Ming-Qing China is compared with early modern Europe to study why China fell behind, and why the Industrial Revolution did not happen in China. Implications of historical experience for the modern era and the future are explored.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2461.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the reasons behind China’s “stagnation” in the past 500 years through comparisons of Ming-Qing China with European nations of the same period.

Derive insights for China’s current economic development based on lessons from the past.
courses.course_syllabus:
Overview of China’s economic development in history

Economic revolution in the Song/Yuan era

Economic development in the Ming/Qing period

China and Europe compared: early modern period similarities and differences in

living standards and technology level

China and Europe compared: market development

China and Europe compared: the rise of capitalism

China and Europe compared: government’s role in the economy

China and Europe compared: ecological constraints and sustained industrial growth

Jiangnan’s industrial development in the Ming/Qing period in comparison with

that of contemporary England. The modern era and the future.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: History of Economic Thought
courses.description: This course traces the development of economic ideas and analysis from ancient times to the present. Emphasis is on the theoretical structure of the mainstream which has made economics a science. Various schools and methodological issues are also discussed in order to compare the paradigms. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Be familiar with the ideas and historical origin of economics.
2) Be able to apply the various logics of the mainstream schools of economic thought.
3) Understand the development of economic thought since mercantilism and classical school.
4) Have a basic idea of schools of economic thought outside the mainstream.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Ancient economic thought before mercantilism
2) Mercantilism
3) Mainstream school of economic thought - Classical School
4) Mainstream school of economic thought - Keynesianism
5) Mainstream school of economic thought – Monetarism
6) The Austrian school, Marxism and other heterodox schools of thought
7) Neoclassical synthesis
8) Mainstream school of economic thought – New Classical School
9) Mainstream school of economic thought – New Keynesianism
10) The future of economic thinking
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, 2) Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, 3) Student consultation.
courses.required_readings: E. K. Hunt and Mark Lautzenheiser, History of Economic Thought, 3rd Edition, Routledge, 2011
courses.recommended_readings:
J. M Keynes, General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money, Prometheus Books, 2005

Milton Friedman and Gary Becker, Milton Friedman on Economics: Selected Papers, University of Chicago Press, 2008

Other readings to be assigned by the course instructor.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economy of China
courses.description: Starting with a review of China’s economy before 1949 as the background, this course covers the following topics in relation to China’s economy from 1949 to the present: growth patterns and structural changes of the macro economy and sectoral economies (agricultural, industrial, tertiary and external sectors); human resources and labour employment; value theory and price issues; wage income, welfare schemes and income policies; economic systems of agricultural, industrial and tertiary sectors; macroeconomic management of public finance, money and banking and foreign trade; and the political economy of Chinese socialism. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Gain a basic understanding of the Chinese economy

2. Understand how China’s institutional landscape shapes China’s economic development and reform

3. Understand the problems of Chinese data critical to the evaluation of China’s economic performance

4. Acquire specific skills for conducting research on the Chinese economy
courses.course_syllabus:
1. From Great Divergence to End of History?

2. Political Governance

3. One Country, Many Fault Lines: Structure and Disparities

4. Macroeconomic Control in Transition

5. The World Factory: China’s Integration with the Global Economy

6. The Last Frontier of Economic Reforms: State-Owned Enterprises

7. Government in Transition: Redefining the Role of the State

8. Central-Local Fiscal Relations in Transition
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course

Informal feedback channels throughout the course (tutorial, face-to-face, email, WebCT)

Departmental retreat

Programme review

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Asia-Pacific Economies
courses.description: This course is a general survey of the economies in the Asia-Pacific region focusing on Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the ASEAN economies. The emphasis is on their economic interrelationships. Topics include: economic growth, export competition, regional trade, protectionism, foreign investment, intra-regional division of labour, migration of capital and labour, and the role of government in economic development. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Enhance the understanding of Asian development issues.

2. Able to examine these issues analytically and critically.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Growth theory and the Asian growth experience

2. Industrial Development: flying geese model, evolution of industrial activities and cluster-based industrial development

3. International Trade Issues: economic integration and the “noodle bowl syndrome”, production network and trade, and trade in services

4. International Financial Issues: financial repression, financial market liberalization, capital flows, Asian financial crisis and financial integration

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: China and the World Economy
courses.description: The rise of China has significant impacts on the world economy. The course examines the major economic issues in the rise of China, the challenges of China to the global economic order, and the effects of Mainland-Hong Kong economic integration on both parties. Well-known research economists and experts from the finance sector and public organizations will be invited to discuss and analyse major issues in the economic cooperation between Hong Kong and the Mainland, e.g. Hong Kong’s integration with the Pearl River Delta and the Mainland, the status of Hong Kong as China’s trading, financial, and services hub, and the impacts on the global economy of the Hong Kong-Mainland economic nexus. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the major issues involved in the rise of the Chinese economy and the impacts on the world economy.
2. Understand the major issues involved in the economic integration of the Hong Kong and the Chinese Mainland.
3. To intelligently discuss and evaluate the debates on these issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. China’s Challenge
2. Financial Crisis and International Economics
3. China’s Opening and Reform
4. Rise of China: Challenges and Opportunities
5. The Global Financial Crisis and China
6. Development of Hong Kong-Mainland Nexus since 1997
7. Special Topics by Guest Speakers
courses.feedback_evaluation:

Informal feedback throughout the course (face to face, email, WebCT)

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Chinese Economy in Transition
courses.description: This course examines the causes and consequences of China’s spectacular economic growth in the past three decades. Exposition of alternative economic systems, incentive problems, and the state-owned enterprises. Analysis of recent reforms and their effects on economic efficiency: rural development, ownership structural changes, financial markets, inflation, population policies, and gradualism versus shock treatment. Exposure to Chinese culture, business practice, and the rise of China in the world economy. The course emphasizes reading and involves extensive class discussions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the causes and consequences of China’s spectacular economic growth in the past three decades.

2. Gain insights on the nature of recent economic reforms and their effects on economic efficiency.

3. Become knowledgeable about major topics in contemporary Chinese economy, including the Great Leap Forward, the dual-track price system, population policies, and gradualism in reforms.

4. Acquire knowledge and skills to engage in debates and discussions on the Chinese economy.

5. Improve skills of writing an analytical paper.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to China’s Great Economic Transformation

2. The Needham Puzzle: Why the Industrial Revolution Did not Originate in China?

3. Comparative Economic Systems

4. China’s Great Leap Forward of 1959-61

5. Rural Institutional Reforms and Growth

6. Inflation and Growth Cycles

7. Population Policies and Demographic Transition

8. International Trade and Trade Policies

9. Gradualist versus Big-Bang Reforms

10. China’s Internal and External Imbalances

and WebCT)

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Business Environment of China
courses.description: Firm performance depends on the environment in which it operates. The course develops, from an economic perspective, an understanding of the basic conditions of the Chinese economy, the culture of the Chinese society, the underlying forces behind the Chinese economic development, the political architecture of China, as well as some key aspects of the Chinese consumer market. The course is reading intensive and requires class discussions. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Gaining an insight of China’s economy and China’s political economy
Developing a sense of business environment in China
courses.course_syllabus:
Module One
Introduction and Approach to the Course
Basic Profile of China

Module Two
Chinese Culture and its implication to China’s Business and Economic Environment

Module Three
Pre-reform History
An Analysis of China’s Political System

Module Four
China’s Economic Reform and Recent Development

Module Five
Segmenting China’s Consumer Markets

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economy of Hong Kong
courses.description: This course covers all major aspects of the Hong Kong economy. Students will have the opportunity to learn how to read economic news and columns, how to collect materials and how to analyse economic issues of Hong Kong by simple theoretical tools. Students are advised to take ECON2011 or ECON2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the basic mechanisms and activities of the Hong Kong economy.
2. Understand and apply relevant basic concepts, tools, and techniques to analysing some current economic issues and policies in Hong Kong.
3. Gain exposure to the economic data of Hong Kong.
4. Improve in writing and verbal communication skills.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Hong Kong’s economic development - Composition of GDP and price indexes, economic performance, structural changes and recent development.
2. International transactions - Hong Kong's BOP positions.
3. Human resources - Labour productivity, cyclical and structural unemployment.
4. Public finance setting - The basic taxation principles and budgetary policies.
5. Income distribution - Gini coefficient and income disparity, poverty and social welfare, human development Index and quality of life.
6. Money and finance - Hong Kong’s monetary system and the linked exchange rate, banking system, stock market, role of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.
7. Real estate market - Land and housing policies.
8. Interaction between Hong Kong and China - Integration with the Mainland, CEPA.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Money and Banking
courses.description:
This course provides a framework for studying the role of money in the economy and the institutional characteristics of the banking system and financial markets. Topics include: the theory and evidence on demand for money, control of money supply and goals and tools of monetary policy, interest rate determination and term structure of interest rates, bank management and operation of the banking system, financial innovation, bank regulation and deregulation, and the linkage between money and economic activity.
To maintain a balance between theory and policy, the course will combine theoretical formalism with empirical investigations of the regularities of the monetary economy. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand money supply and money demand in modern economies.

2. Understand the relation between interest rate and money supply

3. Learn basic frameworks to analyze the interaction between money and the aggregate economy.

4. Gain some insight on how monetary policy is decided and implemented

5. Apply the theories to real-life situations
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basics on Money and Interest Rate

2. Money Supply

3. Tools of Monetary Policy

9. Rational Expectations: Implication for Policy

10. Financial Crisis

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Financial Economics
courses.description: This course covers the basic principles of security valuation, portfolio management and corporate finance. Topics include: consumption smoothing and investment, mean-variance analysis, CAPM, efficient market hypothesis, pricing of stocks, price movements, IPO, capital structure, dividend policy, loan contracts, mergers and acquisitions, and corporate governance. Students are advised to take ECON1101, 2121, 2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the factors determining asset prices in equilibrium.
2. Appreciate the arguments and evidence for and against the efficient market hypothesis.
3. Gain insights on various aspects of corporate financial decisions, such as capital structure, loan contracts, mergers and acquisitions, and corporate governance.
4. Have a sense of the language and operations of financial professionals, and the activities of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
5. Improve in writing and verbal communication skills.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Intertemporal Consumption Allocation, Separation Theorem and NPV Rule
2. Mean-Variance Analysis and Optimal Portfolio Choice
3. Capital Asset Pricing Model and Applications
4. Efficient Market Hypothesis – the theory, Volatility Tests, Limited Arbitrage Theory
5. Empirical Studies of Price Series, Limited Arbitrage Evidence
6. Mutual Fund Returns, Investment Strategies, IPO Underperformance
7. Modigliani-Miller Theorem and its Implications, Corporate Finance
8. Loan Financing – an efficient contract perspective
9. Mergers and Acquisitions – motivations, gainers and losers, evidence
10. Corporate Governance, Owner-Manager Separation, Large Shareholder- Small Shareholder Separation

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Public Finance
courses.description: This course focuses on the application of economic theory to the analysis of the issues pertaining to public expenditures and taxation. The first part of the course discusses theories on public expenditures, such as theories on public goods and social cost benefit analysis. The second part of the course explores the principles and theories of taxation. The features of different kinds of taxes will be analysed. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn economics concepts essential for understanding the public sector, including Pareto efficiency, equity, public goods, externality.

2. Understand the economic rationales behind common public programs.

3. Understand the considerations for designing taxation policies from economists’ perspectives.

4. Understand the potential problems in the public decision-making process, including the difficulties inherent in democratic governments.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic concepts of public finance

2. Welfare theorems

3. Public Goods

4. Clarke-Groves Tax

5. Externalities

6. Pollution Tax versus Quota

7. Poverty

8. Income Distribution

9. Inequality Index

10. Taxation and Behaviours

11. Tax Incidence

12. Optimal Taxation

13. Majority Voting Rule

14. Social Choice

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Urban Economics
courses.description: This course is an introduction to theories of urban phenomena and the analysis of policy problems typical of big cities. Emphasis will be placed on urban land use, housing, transportation and environmental problems. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Understand the economic rationale for the birth and growth of cities

2) Understand the economic and social issues that arise in the development of a city

3) Recognize the stage of urban decline and policies preventing urban decline

4) Be familiar with historical examples of the rise of cities.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction to Urban Economics

2) Location Decisions of households and firms

3) Analysis of Cities, quality of life

4) Urban growth and size of cities

5) Employment in cities

6) Transportation in cities

7) Housing in cities

8) Economics of city-level government
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, 2) Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, 3) Student consultation.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Development Economics

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course is a survey of the problems pertaining to economic development. Topics included are: the concept of development, income distribution, theories of economic development, population and employment problems, agriculture, industry and international trade. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire a basic understanding of the issues and on-going debates in development economics

2. Learn the important models and theories in economic development and their policy implications

3. Acquire training and skills for conducting research related to development economics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Why some nations are so rich and some so poor?

2. Institutions and growth

3. High development theories or random experiments?

4. Is economic growth development?

5. State or market?

6. Trade liberalization and development

7. From financial repression to financial globalization

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Labour Economics

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G03

courses.description: This course emphasizes both theoretical and empirical studies. Topics covered include: static and dynamic models of the demand for labour, allocation of time, the labour supply of men and women, labour unions, human capital theory, theories of personal income distribution, information and search theory, signalling and self-selection, implicit contracts and the principal-agent problem. Students should have knowledge of basic microeconomics and elementary calculus, and are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Having taken this course, students shall be:

• familiar with the terminology and basic facts related to the labour market

• able to understand and explain key features of various labour markets

• capable to evaluate the findings of empirical work

• able to assess the policy implication of various labour policies.
courses.course_syllabus: This course emphasizes both theoretical and empirical studies. Topics covered include: static and dynamic models of the demand for labour, allocation of time, the labour supply of men and women, labour unions, human capital theory, theories of personal income distribution, information and search theory, signalling and self-selection, implicit contracts and the principal-agent problem.
courses.feedback_evaluation:

Reflection of teacher (evidence from student performance in homework assignments, in-class discussions, mid-term exam, and final exam)

Ehrenberg, Ronald G. and Robert S. Smith (2009) Modern Labor Economics: Theory and Public Policy. 10th Edition. Pearson Education, Inc.

Borjas, George (2010) Labor Economics. 5th Edition. McGraw-Hill.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Industrial Organization
courses.description: The main topics of this course include: principal-agent theory, internal organization of the firm, vertical and horizontal integration, contracts, regulation of monopoly, strategic interactions among firms, multinational corporations, research and development activities, and case studies. Students should have knowledge of calculus, and are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Have a good understanding of the theories in industrial organization

2) Gain an ability to apply creatively the theories to understand firms’ interactions.
courses.course_syllabus: The course applies microeconomic theories to the study of the organization of firms, industries, markets, and firm behaviors. It emphasizes strategic interactions among firms as ways to characterize firm behaviors: price setting, entry and exit decisions, vertical integration, R&D, etc. This approach also draws implications on the effects of government policies, including regulations, competition policy and trade policies.

courses.recommended_readings:
Church, Jeffrey, and Roger Ware. 1999. Industrial Organization: A Strategic Approach. Homewood, Ill: Irwin McGraw-Hill.

Friedman, David D. 1990. Price Theory: An Intermediate Text, 2nd Edition. Cincinnati, OH: South-Western Publishing Co.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economies of Social and Environmental Issues
courses.description: This course uses economic theory to analyse topical social and environmental issues including crime and punishment, education, health care system, social security, poverty, democracy, environmental management and resource conservation. The course material is drawn from theoretical and empirical studies of these subjects by economists, and is selected for the benefit of students who have a basic knowledge of economics and mathematics and who would like further understanding of how economics can be applied to subjects of public concern. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Develop an understanding of the roles of societal concerns and environment in economics
2. Understand why the market may fail to achieve optimal environmental outcomes for an economy
3. Understand the economic rationale behind the social problems such as crime, poverty and economic inequality. 4. Develop an intuition for the economic solutions in dealing with social and environmental issues, such as law, punishment, education and government transfers.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1: Environmental Economics
1) Introduction to environmental economics
2) Market efficiency, externalities, and the Coase theorem
3) Pigouvian policies
4) Permits, and Porter hypotheses
5) Cost and benefit analysis
Topic 2: Social Economics
1) Introduction of the role of society in economic analysis
2) Economics of Law
3) Poverty, crime and law enforcement in economics
4) Policies in reducing and deterring criminal activities in economics
5) The role of social security and education
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, 2) Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, 3) Student consultation.
courses.required_readings:
J Le Grand, C Propper & R Robinson, The Economics of Social Problems, Fourth Edition, Palgrave, 2008

Nathaniel O. Keohane and Sheila M. Olmstead, Markets and the Environment, Second edition, Island Press, 2016

Thomas J. Miceli, The Economic Approach to Law, 3rd Edition, Stanford Univ. Press,2017
courses.recommended_readings:
Anthony B Atkinson and Nicholas Barr, Economics of the Welfare State, Fifth Edition, Oxford University Press, 2012
Charles Kolstad, Environmental Economics, 2nd edition, Oxford University Press, 2010

Other readings will be assigned by the course instructor.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Family Economics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the economic analysis of such family behaviour as human capital investment, fertility, mortality, marriage and divorce. It also analyses the courses and consequences of other family issues: bequests, old-age support and social security, sex preferences (boys favoured in many developing countries) and so on. It shows how to use modern microeconomics to analyse these family issues. Real-word examples are examined and possible policy implications are discussed. Students should have knowledge of basic microeconomics and elementary calculus.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the economic rationale behind the formation of families, and its effects on society.

2. Understand the use of economic models in household decisions.

3. Be familiar with economic theories related to contemporary intra-family issues, such as divorce, fertility and offspring gender preference, bequests and old-age supports.

4. Develop an awareness of the latest research on economic issues of families.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction of family economics

2. Unitary and non-unitary models of household behavior

3. Economic models of marriage and divorce, assortative matching

4. Economic Models and empirical studies of fertility

5. Economics of parenting, transferable utility models and household bargaining

6. The quantity-quality tradeoff, the Rotten-Kid theorem

7. China’s One-Child Policy and investment in children

8. Female labour-force participation

9. Social security, bequests, and filial piety

10. Inter-generational issues, mobility, poverty and crime

11. Policies for family formation and fertility.
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, 2) Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, 3) Student consultation.
courses.required_readings: Martin Browning. Pierre André Chiappori and Yoram Weiss, Economics of the Family, Cambridge University Press, 2014
courses.recommended_readings:
Gary Becker, A Treatise on the Family, Harvard University Press, 1991.

Mark Rosenzweig and Oded Stark, Handbook of Population and Family Economics, Elsevier, 1997.

Francine Blau, Marianne Ferber, Anne Winkler, The Economics of Women, Men and Work, 7th edition, Prentice Hall, 2013.

Other readings will be assigned by the course instructor.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics of Capital Markets
courses.description: This course provides an analytical approach to the understanding of the structure and operation of capital markets. Markets for stocks, bonds, currencies, futures, swaps, derivatives, unit trusts, venture capital and hedge funds are discussed. Major topics include: valuation of assets in general, theory of efficient portfolio, the tradeoff between risk and return, hedging and arbitraging, efficient markets, CAPM theory of assets pricing, pricing of futures, Black-Scholes formula for options pricing and the securitization of housing mortgages, etc. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have a good understanding of the structures and operational framework of the various financial markets.

2. To grasp the skills and knowledge in financing, investing and controlling risk by using the financial instruments available in the capital markets.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of the Financial Environment

2. Organization and Structure of Markets

3. Market Microstructure

4. Portfolio Selection: the Mean-Variance Model

5. Risk and Return Theories – Capital Asset Pricing Model

6. Risk and Return Theories – Arbitrage Pricing Theory

7. Stock Markets

8. Market Efficiency and Market Anomalies

9. Determination of Interest Rate & Bond Valuation

10. Interest Rate Risk and Bond Portfolio Strategies

11. Mortgage Markets

Term-end course and teaching evaluation

Intra-term feedback collected from electronic media and face-to-face interactions

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Economic Relations
courses.description: This course offers an introductory view of how the global economic order has developed and what the future might hold, focusing on the evolution of global trading and monetary systems. Theory of international economics and real-world cases are discussed and reviewed. Topics include: protectionism, trade liberalization, regional trade blocs, factor mobility, exchange rate systems, managing currencies and policy cooperation, and debt and currency crisis, etc. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Basic understanding of the behaviour of the global economy
2. Ability to discuss and evaluate the role of markets, policy, and policy cooperation in the global economy
3. Gain insights on major issues involved in global economic integration
courses.course_syllabus:
I. International Trade
1. Comparative Advantage
2. Explaining Trade Patterns
3. Trade Policy
4. Regional Economic Integration
5. Global Companies, Foreign Investment and Labor Migration

II. International Monetary and Financial Relations
1. Balance of Payments
2. Foreign Exchange Rates
3. Fixed and Floating Exchange Rate Systems
4. Macro-Economic Policy in Open Economies

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Foundations of Corporate Finance
courses.description: This course is an introduction to basic concepts in corporate finance and their applications to: (1) valuation of assets and cashflow discounting; (2) evaluation of investment proposals; (3) valuation of risky assets including stocks and bonds; and (4) corporate finance policy decisions including dividend and capital structure policy. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken FINA3088.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To apply the concepts of time value of money in bond and stock valuation.

• To understand and apply asset pricing model when making investment decisions.

• To understand the factors that may affect a firm’s capital structure policy

• To understand the factors that affect a firm’s dividend policy
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: an overview of corporate finance

• Objective of a firm

• Three building blocks: investment decision, financing decision and payout decision

• What can go wrong? Managerial incentives

2. Investment decision

• Background material

- Financial statements and cash flows

- Time value of money

• Bond valuation and stock valuation

• Risk and return

- Valuing financial assets: CAPM, APT

- Valuing real assets

• Capital investment decision and capital budgeting

3. Financing decision

• Some facts from institutional perspective

• Basic concepts of capital structure

• Cost of capital

• Miller-Modigliani Theorem

• Limits to the use of debt

• Capital structure and corporate strategy

4. Payout decision

• Facts about dividend policy

• Revisiting Miller-Modigliani theorem

• Assessing dividend policy
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course

Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
courses.required_readings: Ross, S. A., R.W. Westerfield, and J. Jaffe “Corporate Finance”, 9th edition, 2010, Irwin McGraw Hill
courses.recommended_readings: Brealey, Myers and Allen, Principles of Corporate Finance, 9th edition, 2007, McGraw Hill/Irwin

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Information Technology and Economy
courses.description: The course explores how ever-evolving information technology changes business operations and affects our daily life. The course discusses fundamental concepts and practical applications of information technology especially issues related to its role, cost and benefit. Upon completing the course, students will be aware of the extent to which information technology permeates many aspects of our life. They will also be able to evaluate issues relating to the use of information technology critically. Students are advised to take ECON2011 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEB2580.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand why information technology permeates many aspects of our life.

2. Able to evaluate issues relating to the use of information technology critically.
courses.course_syllabus: The course explores how ever-evolving information technology changes business operations and affects our daily life. The course discusses fundamental concepts and practical applications of information technology, especially issues related to its role, cost and benefit. Upon completing the course, students will be aware of the extent to which information technology permeates many aspects of our life. They will also be able to evaluate issues relating to the use of information technology critically.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Emerging Financial Markets of China
courses.description: The course is an overview of China’s evolving financial system in the reform era. To unravel the inner logic of the Chinese financial system, the course examines the various components of the financial sector, e.g., the banking sector, the foreign exchange market, the money market and the equity market. In addition, the challenges confronting China’s financial sector in the new millennium are explored. Among the special topics discussed are China’s accession to the WTO, the liberalization of interest rates, capital account liberalization, the choice of exchange rate arrangement for renminbi as well as measures to resolve the risks of the financial sector. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Gain a basic understanding of China’s financial system

2. Understand how China’s institutional landscape shapes her financial system

3. Comprehend how China’s financial developments impinge on the global economy

4. Learn the skills and tools in doing research on issues related to China’s financial system
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Financial Structure of China: An Overview

2. From Financial Repression to Liberalization: Opportunities and Challenges

3. Financial Regulatory Framework of China

4. The People’s Bank of China and Monetary Policy

5. Banking Sector: Problems and Restructuring

6. International Finance – Renminbi Exchange Rate

7. International Finance – Capital Account Liberalization

8. Stock Market

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Business Economics
courses.description: This course aims at introducing the basics of the economics of organization and the economics of managerial decisions. Primary focus is on the application of theory to real business decisions, formulation of corporate strategies, and policy-making under a competitive regime and/or a regulatory environment. Students are advised to take ECON2011 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Learn managerial decisions using demand and cost models

2) Apply economic theories in real business situations

3) Formulate pricing and other corporate strategies

4) Understand business strategies under a competitive regime and/or a regulatory environment
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Basic concepts used in economics

2) Consumer demand and estimations

3) Costs and risks

4) Topics on law and economics

5) Topics on government regulation and antitrust

6) Market structure

7) Repeated games and mixed strategies

8) Auctions

9) Oligopoly Models

10) Pricing strategies

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Trade
courses.description: A general survey of the theory of international trade and an examination of its relation to both international and domestic policies. Major topics include: the theory of comparative advantage, international trade and factor prices, income distribution, economic development, trade policy and economic welfare. Students should have knowledge of elementary differential calculus, and are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand basic issues related to the classical trade theory, strategic trade theory and commercial policy, such as tariffs, quotas, export subsidies, etc.
To understand recent developments in globalization, trade liberalization, labor mobility and international investment.

International factor movements

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Macroeconomics
courses.description: The main topics of this course are: international financial markets, the effects of balance of payments disequilibrium and exchange rate changes on the domestic macroeconomy, various approaches to the determination of balance of payments and exchange rates, the evolution and the present condition of the international monetary system, monetary integration, floating vs. fixed exchange rates, and some recent concerns such as the oil price and Third World debt. Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Able to explain the basic concepts of this subject.

2. Apply the economic models and data analyses to discuss some important international financial issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Foreign Exchange Market

2. Exchange Rate Determination in the Short Run and the Long Run:

3. National Income Accounting and the Balance of Payments

4. Floating Exchange Rates and Macroeconomic Policies

5. Fixed Exchange Rate and Managed Intervention

6. Exchange Rate Crises: International Monetary Experience: Fixed versus Floating

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Law and Economics
courses.description: Law and economics use economic theories and empirical tools to understand law. Scholars in the field study the economic consequences of law and seek to identify the kinds of legal rules that would maximize economic efficiency. The course surveys a selected set of law and economics topics including tort, contract, property, crime, corporate, antitrust, etc. Students are advised to take ECON2011 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to:

1. Understand how economics helps study legal issues

2. Analyze certain legal issues using economic theories and empirical tools.

3. Understand how economic efficiency can be used to evaluate legal rules.

4. Deepen their understanding of the various legal issues covered in the course.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What economic analysis of law involves?

2. Efficiency

3. Property

4. Contract

5. Tort

6. Crime

7. Other selected topics of law

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Microeconomics
courses.description: This course covers important developments in microeconomic theory in the last two decades. Emphasis depends on the interest of the instructor. Possible topics include: contract theory, mechanism design, adverse selection, signalling theory, and principal-agent problems. This course is particularly suitable for students who aspire to graduate work. While knowledge of advanced mathematics (such as real analysis, topology, and measure theory) is not required, students should have attained a certain degree of maturity in mathematical thinking. Students are advised to take ECON1111 and 3011 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand how information asymmetry affects economic behaviour under different situations.

2. Appreciate and identify the presence of moral hazard, adverse selection and signalling that students encounter in their daily economic life.

3. Apply what they learn from the course to conceptualize these issues and consider the relevant factors that must be considered in addressing them.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Expected Utility Theory

3. Risk Aversion and Stochastic Dominance

4. The Base Model: Symmetric Information

5. Hidden Action Problem: Moral Hazard

6. Hidden Information Problem: Adverse Selection

7. Hidden Information Problem: Signalling

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Macroeconomics
courses.description: The emphasis of this course is on the modern analysis of macroeconomic fluctuations and growth. Advanced theories of business cycles such as the New Classical and New Keynesian approaches, are studied. It also provides an introduction to models of endogenous growth and technological change. Topics include: dynamic macro models of finite and infinite horizon, monetary growth models, search models, new growth models, and models of income distribution. This course strikes a balance between theoretical developments and empirical studies in modern macroeconomics. This course is particularly suitable for students who aspire to doing graduate work. Students are advised to take ECON1111 and 3021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiar with formal analytical tools in macroeconomics, including overlapping-generation models, infinite-horizon models with representative agents, dynamic general equilibrium approach.

2. Able to apply these frameworks to explore quantitatively and empirically a broad set of economic questions regarding economic growth/development and business cycles.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1: Growth, saving and investment

∙ Kaldor's six stylized facts on growth; the Solow growth model revisited

∙ Endogenizing saving rates in a simple two-period model; Saving rates in a life-cycle model: theory and evidence

∙ Infinite horizon models with representative agents; dynamic general equilibrium

Part 2: Business cycles

∙ Business cycle models with stochastic productivity shocks and endogenous labor supply

∙ Calibration and quantitative results

∙ The Great Depression from a neoclassical perspective

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Introductory Mathematical Economics
courses.description:
This course discusses basic tools in mathematical analysis and their applications to mathematical economics. Mathematical topics include sets, functions, sequences, continuity, open sets, closed sets, compact sets, maximum existence theorem, separating hyperplanes, and fixed points. Economic topics include
preference, utility, demand, competitive equilibrium, and Pareto optimality.
Students should have knowledge of elementary differential calculus, and are advised to take ECON1111 and 2011 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn basic tools in mathematical analysis and their applications to mathematical economics.

2. Learn formal mathematical reasoning, and how to read and write proofs.

3. Learn mathematical tools that are widely used in economic theory, such as logic, sets, functions, sequences, continuity, open sets, closed sets, compact sets, maximum existence theorem, separating hyperplanes, and fixed points.

4. Learn basic results in mathematical economics, such as preference, utility, demand, general equilibrium, Pareto optimality.

5. Improve ability of reading academic papers in economic theory.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Logic and Proofs

2. Sets and Functions

3. Preference and Utility

4. Sequence, Limit, Continuity

5. Existence of Utility Representation

6. Compact Set and Maximizer Existence

7. Consumer Demand

8. Exchange Economy

9. Separating Hyperplanes and Two Welfare Theorems

10. Fixed Points and Existence of Competitive Equilibrium

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Applied Forecasting Methods
courses.description: This course focuses on the estimation and inference of modern econometric forecasting models. Topics include the ARMA model, forecasting trends and seasonality, combination of forecasts, and evaluation of forecasts. Students are advised to take ECON2021 and 3121 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the models used in forecasting economic time series.

2. Learn how to interpret empirical results in this course instead of looking at the numbers in the computer output.

3. Discuss a variety of forecasting issues: forecasting trends, forecasting seasonality, ARIMA processes, combination of forecasts, evaluation of forecasts, and volatility forecasting.

4. Learn well-known statistical software R.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Forecasting problems and forecast objectives; Statistical Reviews: Linear Regression

2. Modeling and forecasting trends and seasonality

3. Characterizing economic cycles

4. Modelling cycles: MA, AR, and ARMA processes

5. Estimation of ARMA model

6. Forecasting from ARMA models

7. Forecasting with multivariate regression models

8. Multiple time-series forecasting models

9. Unit-root and forecasting

10. Cointegration and error correction model

11. Forecasting with system of equations

12. Combination of forecast

13. Evaluation of forecast

14. Volatility measure and forecasting

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Machine Learning Methods in Economics
courses.description:
Data analysis is essential in this big data era. This course covers techniques to obtain and process data from online sources as well as machine learning methods commonly used to analyze such data. Both traditional machine learning and deep learning will be covered.

Students are recommended to have knowledge of basic statistics and regression analysis before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquainted with basic terminologies in social and economic network analysis.
2. Able to perform econometric regressions on network data and provide economic interpretations.
3. Understand the common machine learning techniques used in analyzing data from social media.
4. Able to use software R and Python to collect data and conduct network analysis.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Network data and descriptive statistics
2. Using network statistics in regressions
3. Network structure and diffusion
4. Social interactions and peer effects in networks
5. Network formation
6. Obtaining data from social media
7. Machine learning techniques
a. Analyzing consumer preference
b. Representing graphical data
c. Analyzing text data

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Capstone Project in Data Analytics
courses.description: This course is designed to allow undergraduate students who have taken (or are currently taking) the course of ECON4130 to conduct independent research and write a research paper related to economic or social networks. Students will take this chance to apply the knowledge and technique learnt from ECON4130 and study deeper into specific topics of their interests. Students and the instructor will meet regularly to discuss each step of the research process. Students are expected to submit their theses at the end of the course.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Welfare Economics
courses.description: This course introduces students to basic concepts in welfare economics to allow an understanding of important economic factors affecting the level of social welfare. The conditions for Pareto optimality, alternative welfare criteria, measures of consumer surplus, optimal income distribution, external effects, public goods, the theory of second best and the basic theory of social choice will be discussed. Students are advised to take ECON2011 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand why and when public policies are required to enhance the efficiency of an economy.

2. Understand why sometimes piece-meal policy reforms are not beneficial and a holistic perspective is needed for policy.

3. Understand the difficulties in formulating a collective decision on a rational basis while individuals’ opinions are respected.

4. Understand the basic methods and constraints of using consumer surplus to assess the costs and benefits of policies or public projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Welfare economics and welfare

2. Theory of individual choice

3. Welfare criteria

4. Theory of social choice

5. Fundamental welfare theorems

6. Theories of market failure

7. Theory of the second best

8. Marshallian consumer surplus

9. Equivalent and compensating variations
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course

Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)

Departmental Retreat

Programme Review

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics of Derivatives
courses.description:
This course is designed as an introduction to the markets for derivatives. It covers most of the widely used derivative securities in practice, such as futures contracts, interest-rate and currency swaps, and various options. During the course we shall discuss, among others, the uses of derivatives in risk management, valuation of derivatives, the risk-neutral valuation principle, the Black-Scholes formula, binomial trees approach and portfolio insurance. Though not a prerequisite, a minimum background in corporate finance and/or financial markets will be desirable.
Students are advised to take ECON2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To understand how forwards and futures market work

• To compute the price of forwards and futures across asset classes

• To understand the types and payoffs of options

• To compute the price and price range of options

• To design hedging strategies and implement risk management using derivatives
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to futures and forwards

• Hedging Strategies using Futures

• Determination of Forward and Futures Prices

• Introduction to Options

• Properties of Stock Options

• Options Trading Strategies

• Option Prices: Binomial Trees

• Option Prices: Wiener Processes and Ito’s Lemma

• Option Prices: Black-Scholes partial differential equation

• Hedging Risk: Greek Letters

• Application: Options on Stock Indices, Currencies and Futures
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation at end of course

Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)
courses.required_readings: • Hull, John C. Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives, 7th Edition, Pearson, 2009
courses.recommended_readings: McDonald Robert, Derivatives Markets, 1st edition, Addison Wesley, 2002

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economic Growth and Technological Change
courses.description: This expository course attempts to provide an introduction to the rapidly expanding study of endogenous growth and technological change. The main focuses will be on studying the forces that determine the growth process of an economy over long periods of time and examining various policies that governments can use to try to influence the rate of growth. Topics include: exogenous growth models, endogenous growth models, R & D and growth, human capital and growth, specialization and economic progress, and government policies to raise long-run living standards. This course strikes a balance between theoretical developments and empirical studies. Students are advised to take ECON1111, 2011 and 2021 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Be familiar with the canonical economic growth theories and the associated models

2) Understand the elements of dynamic programming

3) Be familiar with the latest developments of growth theories

4) Understand the role of technology and human capital, in relation to economic growth

5) Develop an understanding on how policies can influence economic growth
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction to economic growth

2) Growth accounting

3) Exogenous growth models and dynamic programming

4) Endogenous growth models 1 – Romer AK Model

5) Endogenous growth models 2 – Romer 2 sectors model

6) Role of human capital in endogenous growth theories

7) Specialization and economic growth

8) Role of government in economic growth

9) Applications and numerical simulation of economic growth models
courses.feedback_evaluation: 1) Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, 2) Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, 3) Student consultation.
courses.required_readings: D. Acemoglu, Introduction to Modern Economic Growth, Princeton University Press, 2009
courses.recommended_readings:
C. Jones and D. Vollrath, Introduction to Economic Growth. W. W. Norton & Co., 2013

David Weil, Economic Growth, 3rd Edition, Routledge, 2012

Other readings will be assigned by the course instructor.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics of Behavioural Finance

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description: This course introduces you to the relatively new field of behavioural finance. We explore implications of non-standard behavioural assumptions on finance theories. We will cover both theoretical and empirical aspects of the field. Students are advised to take ECON3420 or 3540 or 4450 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, the student will be able to:
1. Demonstrate understanding of the key behavioral assumptions in economics and finance.
2. Argue for and against the plausibility of the theories.
3. Recognize how behavioural theories were tested and applied empirically.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1-2
- Review of standard asset pricing models
- Does CAPM works in practice?
- Fama-French Three-Factor Model
Week 3-4
- The Deposition Effect: Reference-Dependent Preference
- Anticipatory Utility
Week 5-6
- Teaser Interest Rate: Time-inconsistency
- Projection Bias
Week 7
- Midterm
Week 8-9
- Savings and Retirement: Default Options
- Effects of Commitment Devices on Savings
Week 10-11
- Mental Accounting
- Overconfidence
- Efficiency of Market: Noise Traders and Momentum Traders
Week 12-13
- The Close-End Fund Puzzle
- Behavioral Models in Corporate Finance

Course and teaching evaluation at end of course
Informal feedback channels throughout the course (face-to-face, email, WebCT)

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Guided Study in Current Economic Problems II
courses.description:
The major concern is the application of student-oriented method of teaching to the analysis of current economic problems. Students are required to do research on topics related theoretically or empirically to current economic problems under the intensive guidance of a teacher. The requirements include the writing of research reports, presentation of papers and participation in class discussion.
(Advisory: Course designed for students in their final year of major study in ECON. Students are advised to take ECON2901, 3011 and 3021 before taking this course. Capacity limited. Priority given to students in their final year of major study in ECON.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
- gain ability to design an appropriate research project
- apply technical skills learnt in other course to research
- be able to present research results effectively both in written and oral form
courses.course_syllabus: The major concern is the application of student-oriented method of teaching to the analysis of current economic problems. Students are required to do research on topics related theoretically or empirically to current economic problems under the intensive guidance of a teacher. The requirements include the writing of research reports, presentation of papers and participation in class discussion.
