courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics - Theory and Reality
courses.description:
This course, designed for final year majors, aims at integrating holistically the economics knowledge acquired by the student from the diverse major and elective courses prescribed in the programme. In particular, students are guided to apply what they have learnt to analyze and understand real economic events and to predict future trends. Economic issues and problems of current interest will be emphasized. In addition, professional economists in the fields will be invited to give sharing sessions so that students can appreciate the power of economic models in their applications to real issues and the skills employed in such applications. In the process, students gain useful insights in the demands of different occupations and become better informed in their own career planning.

(Advisory: Course designed for students in their final year of major study in ECON. Students are advised to take ECON2901, 3011 and 3021 before taking this course. Capacity limited. Priority given to students in their final year of major study in ECON.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will:
1. be able to employ their economic knowledge to analyze certain economic events and issues of current interest,
2. appreciate how economic models are utilized for real applications in professional job environments, and
3. be able to plan for their own career paths.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics vary according to the issues of current interest. There are two essential components.
First, lectures and discussion sessions are held on topics of current interest – economic issues that prospective employers expect economic graduates to understand.
Second, sharing sessions are held by invited professional economists to expose students to their work environments and the demands of their positions through studying specific cases of economic application. An essential topic is how students can plan career paths that best suit their backgrounds and strengths.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Formal course evaluation at end of course.
Feedbacks from students in annual departmental retreat.
Feedbacks from visiting committee and programme review.
Feedbacks from guest speakers.
courses.required_readings: To be prescribed in the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings: To be prescribed in the course outline.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics in Practice
courses.description:
This course, designed for final year majors, aims at integrating holistically the economics knowledge acquired by the student from the diverse major and elective courses prescribed in the programme. In particular, students are guided to apply what they have learnt to analyze and understand real economic events and to predict future trends. Economic issues and problems of current interest will be emphasized. Alumni and professionals working in related fields will be invited to give sharing sessions so that students can appreciate the power of applying economic knowledge to real issues and the skills employed in such applications. In the process, students gain useful insights in the demands of different occupations and become better informed in their own career planning.

(Advisory: Course designed for students in their final year of major study in ECON. Students are advised to take ECON2901, 3011 and 3021 before taking this course. Capacity limited. Priority given to students in their final year of major study in ECON.)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will:
1. be able to employ their economic and technical knowledge to analyze economic events and issues of current interest,
2. appreciate how economic knowledge is utilized for real applications in professional job environments, and
3. be able to plan for their own career paths.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics vary according to the issues of current interest. There are three essential components.
First, lectures and discussion sessions are held on topics of current interest – economic issues and technical skills that prospective employers expect economic graduates to understand.
Second, sharing sessions are held by invited alumni and professionals to expose students to their work environments and the demands of their positions through studying specific cases of economic application. An essential topic is how students can plan career paths that best suit their backgrounds and strengths.
Third, students will present in a public poster presentation session. This trains students' ability to explain economic findings to layman with little formal training in the discipline.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Senior Thesis Research I
courses.description:
A student may enrol in this special research course with the permission and under the supervision of an instructor. The content of the course will depend on the research plans of the student. The student must submit a thesis at the end of the course.
Senior Thesis I and II can be taken independently. For a student taking both courses consecutively, the paper submitted in the course taken later can be (1) a substantial extension of the paper submitted before or (2) a new paper on a different topic.
(Advisory: Course designed for students in their final year of major study in ECON. Capacity limited. Priority given to students in their final year of major study in ECON.)
courses.learning_outcomes: To gain experience in conducting individual research under faculty guidance, culminating in a thesis that embodies an insightful survey of relevant literature, original thinking, and competent analyses of theoretical models or datasets.
courses.course_syllabus:
To be determined with the help of thesis supervisor.

To be offered in Term 1.

This course has no relationship with ECON4920. Students may choose one or both of ECON4910 and ECON4920, and in any sequence.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Microeconomic Theory I
courses.description: This course provides an exposition of advanced microeconomic theory. It is the first part of a sequence of two courses on microeconomic theory for M.Phil and PhD students. Topics include preference and utility, consumer theory, expected utility theory, risk aversion, and general equilibrium.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: To equip students with advanced knowledge in microeconomic theory, providing a solid foundation for more advanced studies in theory and applied fields. Students should be capable of conducting individual studies of original articles in journals. Students should also acquire skills in economic modeling.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Choice, preferences, and utility (lectures 1-3 [R], Ch. 3A-C [MWG])
2. The consumer problem: convex preferences, Marshallian demand (Ch. 2 A-E, Ch. 3 D [MWG], lecture 4 [R], Ch 3 [K])
3. Revealed preferences and Afriat's theorem (Ch. 4 [K])
4. Expenditure minimization, Hicksian demand, duality, and Slutsky decomposition (Ch. 3. E, F, G [MGW], lecture 6 [R], Ch 10.1-6 [K])
5. Classical and behavioral welfare economics ( Ch. 3 I [MWG])
6. Choice under uncertainty: the independence axiom, expected utility, and the Allais paradox (lecture 8 [R], Ch. 6 A-C [MWG], Ch. 5 [K])
7. Mid-term (Lecture 1-5)
8. Utility for money and risk aversion (Lecture 9 [R], Ch. 6 [K])
9. First and second order stochastic dominance (Ch. 6.D [MWG])
10. Measuring risk preferences, Rabin's calibration theorem, reference point and loss aversion
11. Introduction to general equilibrium (Ch. 15 [MWG], Ch 14 1-3 [K])
12. First and second welfare theorems, convergence to the core (Ch. 16 A-D, Ch 18 A,B [MWG], Ch. 15 [K])
13. Existence of general equilibrium (Ch. 17 A-C, E [MWG], Ch 14.4 [K])
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, Student consultation during annual departmental retreat
courses.required_readings:
1. Lecture Notes in Microeconomic Theory [R], 2006, Ariel Rubinstein, Princeton University Press (Free downloads from Rubinstein's webpage)
2. Microeconomic Theory [MWG], 1995, Mas- Colell, Whinston, and Green, Oxford University Press
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Microeconomic Foundations 1: Choice and Competitive Markets [K], 2013, David Kreps, Princeton University Press
2. Notes on the Theory of Choice [K2], 1988, by David Kreps, Westview Press

courses.description: This course provides an exposition of advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer theory, general equilibrium, choice under uncertainty, game theory, and markets with asymmetric information, etc. Emphasis is placed on how these theories are constructed, and the grasp of their analytical tools.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Consumer theory**

* Preferences and utility, Marshallian and Hicksian demand, indirect utility function, expenditure function, Slutsky equation, revealed preference.

* *General equilibrium**

* Exchange economy, Pareto efficiency, competitive equilibrium, first and second welfare theorems, existence of competitive equilibrium.

* *Choice under uncertainty**

* Independence Axiom, expected utility theory.

* *Game theory**

* Strategic games: dominance, Nash equilibrium, Bayesian Nash equilibrium;
* Extensive games: backward induction, subgame perfect equilibrium, sequential equilibrium.

* *Markets with asymmetric information**

* Information asymmetry and adverse selection in market for lemons, signaling in job market, screening in insurance market;
* Principal-agent problem: hidden action and moral hazard, hidden information and monopolistic screening.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
The lecture is mainly based on the lecture notes. Students are also encouraged to read the following references:

* A. Mas-Colell, M. Whinston and J. Green, Microeconomic Theory, Oxford University Press, 1995.
* G. Jehle and P. Reny, Advanced Microeconomic Theory, 3rd Edition, Prentice Hall, 2011.
* M. Osborne and A. Rubinstein, A Course in Game Theory, MIT, 1994.
courses.recommended_readings: The students are recommended to read relevant journal articles given by the instructors.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Macroeconomic Theory I
courses.description: This course covers state-of-art core materials in dynamic macroeconomics at the entry graduate level. It is the first course of a sequence of two courses on macroeconomic theory for M.Phil and PhD students. The course is separated into two parts. In the first part of the course, essential mathematical tools for solving dynamic systems are introduced, including dynamic programming (for discrete time problems) and optimal control theory (for continuous time systems). In the second part of the course, work-horse macroeconomic models are covered including (but not limited to) neoclassical growth model, overlapping-generations model (OLG), and asset pricing model under complete markets.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, graduate students (MPhil/PhD) should:

- Be familiar with tools, modeling techniques as well as economic intuitions in understanding and conducting modern macroeconomic research.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. General Equilibrium Foundations of Growth Theory
2. “Math Camp”: Dynamic Programming and Optimal Control
3. Neoclassical and Endogenous (AK) Growth Models
4. Overlapping Generations (OLG) Model
5. Stochastic Dynamic Programming and Stochastic Growth
6. Equilibrium with Complete Markets and Asset Pricing

(2) Acemoglu Daron. Introduction to Modern Economic Growth, Princeton University Press, February 2009.
(3) Ljungqvist Lars, and Thomas Sargent. Recursive Macroeconomic Theory, 2nd edition, MIT Press, 2004

courses.description: This course introduces the approaches and methods used in modern macroeconomics. The main goal of this course is to equip students with the basic economic intuitions and modeling techniques needed for further exploration in macroeconomic research. The course is divided into two parts. In Part 1 (Economic Growth), students will learn the modern analysis of economic growth. Basic growth theory, growth and development accounting will first be covered. Then new directions on the theories of growth and development will be studied, including an introduction of different models of endogenous growth and technological change. In Part 2 (Foundations of Modern Macroeconomics), important background and computational knowledge of macroeconomics beyond the Classical and Keynesian schools will be covered, including an introduction to Dynamic Programming, Real Business Cycle Theory and introductory macroeconometrics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students are expected to:

* Gain a good understanding of the canonical macroeconomic models and the theories behind such models.
* Become familiar with the methods used in generating qualitative and quantitative forecasts for the purpose of evaluating the effects of macroeconomic policies and shocks on the domestic economy in the short run.
* Appreciate the driving forces behind the growth of the macroeconomy and their implications.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Part 1 - Economic Growth**
1. Introduction
2. Growth and Development Accounting
3. The Neoclassical Growth Models
4. The Endogenous Growth Models
5. Models of Endogenous Technical Change: Product Variety and Schumpeterian
6. Stages of Growth

* *Part 2 - Foundations of Modern Macroeconomics**
1. History of Modern Thoughts on Macroeconomics
2. Dynamic Programming
3. Numerical Dynamic Programming
4. Real Business Cycle Theory
6. Central Bank Independence
7. Elements of Macroeconometrics
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
* *Part 1 (Economic Growth)**

1. Vollrath, D., Jones, C. I., Introduction to Economic Growth, 3rd Edition, W. W. Norton.
2. Aghion, P. and Howitt, P., The Economics of Growth, The MIT Press.
3. Zhu, X., 2012. Understanding China's Growth: Past, Present, and Future, Journal of Economic Perspectives 26 (4), 103-124.
4. Caselli, Francesco, Accounting for Income Differences across Countries, in Handbook of Economic Growth, Vol. 1A, P. Aghion and S. Durlauf, eds. (Amsterdam: Elsevier, 2005, Chap. 9).
5. Jones, C.I., The Facts of Economic Growth, in Handbook of Macroeconomics, Vol. 2A, (Amsterdam: Elsevier, 2016, Chap. 1)

* *Part 2 (Foundations of Modern Macroeconomics)**

1. Heijdra, B. 2017. Foundations of Modern Macroeconomics, Oxford University Press
2. Miranda, M.J., and Fackler P.L. 2002. Applied Computational Economics and Finance, The MIT Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Ljungqvist L. and Sargent T.J. 2000. Recursive Macroeconomic Theory, The MIT Press.
2. Other readings to be assigned by the course instructors.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Macroeconomic Analysis and Applications
courses.description: This course covers modern developments in major macroeconomic theories related to long term growth and short term business cycle changes. Emphasis is given to the applications of modern macroeconomic methods in producing quantitative forecasts and predictions, as practiced in principal macroeconomic research organizations such as central banks and investment groups. Topics featured in the course include: (1) Dynamic Programming, (2) Computable General Equilibrium Models, (3) Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium Models, (4) Macroeconometrics and (5) Bayesian Methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking the course, students should be confident in the use of the major tools in generating quantitative macroeconomic forecasts and predictions at a level similar to those practiced in principal professional research organizations. They are expected to generate independent professional research analysis reports on economic outlooks at the quantitative level, supported by rigorous economic theories and techniques.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Modern Macroeconomic Analysis
2. Essentials on Computations
3. Dynamic Programming
4. Numerical Dynamic Programming
5. Computable General Equilibrium Models
6. Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium Models
7. Macroeconometrics
8. Bayesian Methods in Macroeconomic Analysis and Applications

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Microeconomic Theory II
courses.description: This course is the second part of a sequence of two courses on microeconomic theory for M.Phil and PhD students. It covers applied game theory and its applications: principal-agent problems, economics of information, auctions, bargaining, public goods provision, mechanism design, and market design. This module aims to provide students rigorous and accessible explanations. The objective is to focus on classic results. If time permits, we will also take the students to the frontiers of research in selected areas.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics;Prerequisite: ECON5010
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Static games
• Normal form games, Nash equilibrium
• Bayesian games, Bayesian equilibrium
3. Dynamic games
• Dynamic games with complete information, Subgame-perfect equilibrium
• Dynamic games with incomplete information, Perfect Bayesian equilibrium
4. Information economics
• Market for Lemons
• Communication
• Bayesian persuasion
• Principal-agent problem
5. Allocation mechanisms: bargaining and auction
• Nash, Rubinstein bargaining
• First price auction, Second price auction, Revenue equivalence theorem
6. Mechanism design
• Screening
• Single unit auction, Public goods, Bilateral trade
7. Market design
• Two-sided matching, School choice, Deferred acceptance algorithm
• One-sided matching, Housing market

courses.required_readings: There is no required textbook for this course. The lecture is mainly based on lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. A course in game theory [M]. Osborne M J, Rubinstein A., MIT press, 1994.
2. The theory of incentives: the principal-agent model [M]. Laffont J J, Martimort D., Princeton University Press, 2009.
3. An introduction to the theory of mechanism design [M]. Börgers T, Oxford University Press, 2015.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Macroeconomic Theory II
courses.description: This course covers state-of-art core materials of modern macroeconomics including both theories and applications. It is the second course of a sequence of two courses on macroeconomic theory for M.Phil and PhD students. In the theory section, topics featured include: (1) Structural change and unified growth models, (2) Microfoundation of economic growth including misallocation, innovation and production network etc., and (3) Business cycle theories including Real Business Cycles and the New Keynesian frameworks. The application section of the course emphasizes the use of firm-level or aggregate data in the conduct of macroeconomic research using the above theories.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics;Prerequisite: ECON5020
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, graduate students (M.Phil./ Ph.D.) should be:

- Familiar with tools, modeling techniques as well as economic intuitions in growth and business cycle theories.

- Expected to obtain the ability to understand the driving forces behind the growth process of an economy both at the micro and aggregate level.

- Able to use the DSGE framework in doing independent research about business cycle fluctuations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Models of structural change and its application.
2) Unified growth models and its applications.
3) Misallocation.
4) Innovation and Imitation.
5) Production Network.
6) Real business cycles.
7) New Keynesian Framework.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Review of Quantitative Methods
courses.description: This course reviews mathematical methods frequently used in economic analysis. The following topics will be covered: elementary real analysis, matrix algebra and static analysis, multivariate differential calculus and comparative static analysis, optimizations with constraints, dynamic analysis of difference and differential equations, and dynamic optimization. We assume that students are familiar with basic calculus and elementary linear algebra.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Elementary Real Analysis
Metrics and Norms, Sequences, Open and Closed Sets, Continuity, Compact Sets, Extreme Value Theorem, Convex Sets and Separating Hyperplanes, Correspondences, Fixed Point Theorems, Contraction mapping principles, Cauchy Sequences, Connected sets, Heine-Borel Theorem

2. Matrix Algebra and Static Analysis
Matrix Algebra, Rank, Determinant, Linear Equation Systems, Cramer’s Rule, Vector Space, Linear Independence and Dimension

3. Multivariate Differential Calculus and Comparative Static Analysis
Mean Value Theorem, Taylor Polynomials, Inverse Function Theorem, Implicit Function Theorem, Homogeneous and Homothetic Functions, Concavity and Quasiconcavity

4. Optimization Theory
Optimization with equality and/or inequality constraints, Lagrangian Method, First-Order and Second-Order Conditions, Kuhn-Tucker Conditions, Constraint Qualification, Envelope Theorem and Duality Theory

5. Dynamical Analysis of Difference and Differential Equations
Eigenvalue and Eigenvector, First-Order and Higher-Order Differential Equations and Difference Equations, Simultaneous Differential Equations and Difference Equations

6. Dynamic Optimization
Pontryagin's Maximum Principle, Hamiltonian Function, Bellman Equation, Principle of Optimality
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, Student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
Required textbooks: C. P. Simon and L. Blume, Mathematics for Economists, Norton, 1994.
A. C. Chiang and K. Wainwright, Fundamental Methods of Mathematical Economics, McGraw-Hill, 2005.
courses.recommended_readings: Sydsæter, K., P. Hammond, A. Seierstad, A. Strøm: Further Mathematics for Economic Analysis. Prentice Hall, Inc., London, 2005.

courses.description: This course reviews mathematical methods frequently used in economic analysis. courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Mathematics for Economic Analysis
courses.description: This course introduces the essential mathematical methods for economic analysis. To underscore the relevance of mathematics to economics, this course motivates the study of mathematical methods with the analytical needs of economists, and illustrates the study with appropriate economic applications. The following topics will be covered: elementary real analysis, linear models and matrix algebra for static or equilibrium analysis, differential calculus and comparative static analysis for general function models, optimizations with constraints, differential and difference equations and dynamic optimization. Basic calculus and elementary linear algebra are prerequisites.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Applied Economics

* C. P. Simon and L. Blume, Mathematics for Economists, Norton, 1994.
courses.recommended_readings: * Strøm, and A. Carvajal, Essential Mathematics for Economic Analysis, 5th Edition, Pearson, 2016.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Mathematical Economics
courses.description:
This course discusses several topics in mathematical economics, including utility theory, demand theory, general equilibrium theory, and social choice theory. This course also discusses related mathematical tools, including continuity, open sets, closed sets, compact sets, maximum existence theorem, separating hyperplanes, and fixed points.

Students should have knowledge of elementary differential calculus.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will learn applications of mathematical concepts and techniques to economic theory. Students will improve their mathematical skills and analytical abilities. Students will also improve their abilities of reading academic papers and conducting researches.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Mathematical tools
2. Utility Theory
3. Consumer Demand
4. General Equilibrium Theory
5. Social Choice Theory

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Econometric Theory and Applications
courses.description: Econometrics offers quantitative methods to process and interpret economic data. This is an entry-level postgraduate econometrics course. Under the asymptotic framework, it covers estimation and inference of the regression models and the instrumental variable models. Probability and statistical theory is applied to systematically study the properties of these estimators.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics or MPhil Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Having taken this course, students should be able to
- understand postgraduate level econometric concepts such as linear regression, maximum likelihood, and GMM estimation methods.
- derive asymptotic distributions of OLS and 2SLS and the related test statistic.
- interpret regression results reported by statistical software.
courses.course_syllabus:
\* Conditional expectation and linear projection
\* Least squares estimator I: linear algebra
\* Least squares estimator II: likelihood and exact distribution
\* Basic asymptotic theory I: limits and modes of convergence
\* Basic asymptotic theory II: applications
\* Hypothesis testing I: concept
\* Hypothesis testing II: applications
\* Panel data models
\* Endogeneity and instruments
\* Generalized method of moments
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, Student consultation during annual departmental retreat
courses.required_readings:
Textbooks:
• Hansen (2020): Introduction to Econometrics (https://www.ssc.wisc.edu/~bhansen/probability/)
• Hansen (2020): Econometrics (http://www.ssc.wisc.edu/~bhansen/econometrics/)
courses.recommended_readings:
\* Econometrics, Hayashi, Princeton, 2000
\* Microeconometrics: Methods and Applications, Cameron and Trivedi, Cambridge, 2005

courses.description: Econometrics combines economics, mathematics, and statistics; with its applications involving real data analysis and computer programming. This course is an introductory course in econometrics at the graduate level. It covers basic econometric theory including linear model, large sample theory, estimation methods, hypotheses testing, panel data models, generalized method of moments, discrete choice and censored data, etc., with applications to many real world economic problems using data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
After finishing this course, students are expected to:

* Understand graduate level econometric concepts such as linear and non-linear regression, maximum likelihood, and GMM estimation methods.
* Have a comprehensive understanding of empirical econometric methods.
* Acquire sufficient knowledge to read academic papers and technical policy reports.
* Be equipped with programming skills in R, MATLAB, STATA, etc.
* Be capable of conducting empirical analysis using real data.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Conditional expectation and linear projection
2. Classical multiple regression model
3. Least squares estimator
4. Basic asymptotic theory
5. Hypothesis testing and statistical inference
6. Estimating systems of equations
7. Endogeneity and instruments
8. Generalized method of moments
9. Panel data models
10. Difference in differences
11. Maximum likelihood methods
12. Discrete choice and censored regression
13. Empirical case studies

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Econometric Analysis and Applications
courses.description: Econometrics combines economics, mathematics, statistics with its applications involving real data analysis and computer programming. This course is an introductory course on the applications of econometric analysis at the graduate level. Topics include: linear model, large sample theory, parameters estimation methods, hypotheses testing, panel data models, discrete choice and censored data, etc., with applications to many real world economic problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
After finishing this course, students are expected to

* Have a comprehensive understanding of empirical econometric methods.
* Acquire sufficient knowledge to understand academic journal articles and technical policy reports.
* Be equipped with programming skills in R, MATLAB, STATA, etc.
* Be capable of conducting empirical analysis using real data.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Conditional expectation and linear projection
2. Classical multiple regression model
3. Least squares estimator
4. Basic asymptotic theory
5. Hypothesis testing and statistical inference
6. Estimating systems of equations
7. Endogeneity and instruments
8. Generalized method of moments
9. Panel data models
10. Difference in differences
11. Maximum likelihood methods
12. Discrete choice and censored regression
13. Empirical case studies

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Applied Time Series Analysis
courses.description: This is an econometrics course in time series methods. Topics covered include: stationary ARMA processes, dynamic modeling, univariate with unit roots, cointegration and time series models of heteroskedasticity. Empirical analyses and applications of time series method to real world data will also be provided.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics or Local/ Offshore MSc Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Having taken this course, students should

- have an understanding of time-series econometric estimation and testing methods

- have the ability to pursue an econometric research project for forecasting purposes
courses.course_syllabus:
PART I

1. Introduction to Stationary Stochastic Processes

2. Univariate Time Series Models

(a) ARMA models

(b) Estimation in the time domain

3. Multivariate Time Series Models

(a) Vector autoregressive models

4. Asymptotic Theory for Weakly Dependent Processes

5. Spectrum and Frequency Domain Analysis

PART II

1. The Functional Central Limit Theorem

2. Unit Root Processes

3. Cointegration and Multivariate Models

PART III

1. State-Space Models and Kalman Filter

2. Volatility Models

3. Quantile Regression in Time Series

4. Models with Time Varying Parameters

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Forecasting Methods
courses.description: This course is concerned with the theoretical and applied aspects of economic forecasting. Emphasis is on econometric approaches to forecasting, modeling and forecasting with univariate time series models, functional data analysis, combination of forecasts, machine learning methods, big data, artificial intelligence, and evaluation of forecasts. Applications of the methods to forecast key macroeconomic time series of the Hong Kong and world economy are also discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of this course, students are expected to master theoretical properties of some commonly used forecasting models as well as their applications in macroeconomics, finance, sports, and health. Students should also be able to skillfully select appropriate models to fit real data sets and generate forecasts, evaluate the forecasts performances as well as backtesting. The skills gain through this unit of study will form a strong foundation to work in a financial industry or in a related research organization.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review of Linear Regression Model: an Example with Trend and Seasonality
2. Characterizing and Modeling Cycles: ARMA, ARIMA and SARIMA and their properties
3. Large Sample Theory for Stationary Process
4. Functional Limit Theory and Unit Root Asymptotics
5. Testing for Unit Roots: Dickey- Fuller Tests, PP Tests, ADF Tests and KPSS Tests
6. Co-integration and Error Correction: Representation, Estimation, Testing
7. Conditional Heteroscedastic Models, including ARCH, GARCH
8. Functional data analysis in time series models
9. Model averaging
10. Machine learning methods in time series models
11. High-dimensional time series analysis
12. Topics in Artificial Intelligence and Forecasting
13. Evaluation of forecasts

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Applied Econometrics
courses.description: This is a graduate level course in applied econometrics. Both microeconometric theory and empirical strategies for applied econometric research will be discussed. Modern causal inference including machine learning tools and big data analysis will be introduced. This course will discuss instrumental variable methods, treatment effect, matching, panel data models, differences-in-differences, regression discontinuity designs, binary response model, censored data, and modern causal inference topics including machine learning in causal inference, and so on. Students are advised to take ECON5120/ ECON5121/ ECON5122 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Expected Learning Outcomes:
After finishing this course, students are expected to
1. have a deep and comprehensive understanding of empirical econometric methods.
2. acquire sufficient econometric knowledge to write academic papers in applied economics and technical policy reports.
3. be familiar with the frontiers of modern applied econometrics research, modern machine learning methods and its applications in economic studies.
4. equip with programming skills in STATA, R, or Matlab.
courses.course_syllabus:
Tentative course outline by topics:
1. Randomized controlled trial
2. Linear models and least squares estimator
3. Basic asymptotic theory
4. Model selection
5. Estimating systems of equations
6. Endogeneity and instruments
7. Generalized method of moments
8. Internal and external validity
9. Panel data models
10. Maximum likelihood methods
11. Discrete choice and censored regression\*
12. Treatment effect\*
13. Difference-in-differences\*
14. Regression discontinuity designs\*
15. Machine learning methods

\* The selective topics will be covered in class if schedule allows.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Game Theory
courses.description: This is an advanced course on game theory. We will cover topics in strategic games, extensive games of complete and incomplete information, epistemic foundations of game theory, repeated games, bargaining theory, coalitional games and matching theory. We will also discuss various applications of game theory in Economics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, Student consultation during annual departmental retreat.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Computational Methods in Economics
courses.description: In modern economic research, computers enhance our capacity of solving complex problems. Computation is particularly important in fields involving massive data. The objective of this course is to introduce graduate students to computational approaches to solve economic models, with an emphasis on dynamic programming and simulation-based econometric methods. We will formulate economic problems in computationally tractable form and use techniques of numerical analysis to solve them. Substantive applications will cover a wide range of problems including labor, industrial organization, macroeconomics, and international trade.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics;Prerequisite: ECON5020/ ECON5021/ ECON5022 and ECON5120/ ECON5121/ ECON5122
courses.learning_outcomes: Computational economics has not been part of the core curriculum of postgraduate-level economics education, whereas programming skill is critical for a postgraduate's success in academia and industry. This course intends to teach students computational methods for solving economic problems, and expose students to extensive programming exercises. We expect that at the end of the course a student would proficiently use at least one programming language (Stata, Matlab, R, etc). Moreover, we aim to equip the students with the computational ability to tackle problems of their own research areas.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic Stata
2. Statistical functionality in Stata
3. Basic Matlab
4. Advanced Matlab
5. Monte Carlo Simulation
6. Linear programming
7. Nonlinear programming
8. Approximation methods
9. Numerical Integration
10. Dynamic programming
11. Numerical Optimization
12. Bootstrap

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics and Data Science
courses.description: This is a weekly reading group discussing recent literature that combines novel data with the new generation of tools from data science to answer questions in political economy, law and economics, and other topics in economics (e.g., economic history) and broader social sciences. We will discuss how and why machine learning works, in what way the new method and potentially new forms of data contribute to our knowledge, and new venues where deployment of such tools can be fruitful.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: The key objective of this class is to bring students to the frontier of research that find new ways to explore and work with data in the age of "Big Data". Students should develop a solid understanding of what makes machine learning work conceptually, how they relate to and complement standard econometric tools, and be able to write a chapter in the thesis that incorporate these tools.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of machine learning methods
2. Key principles that make machine learning work
3. Prediction problem
4. Machine learning for causal inference
5. Natural Language Processing (NLP) introduction
6. Text as data
7. Unsupervised learning
8. Other new data
9. Neural network and deep learning
10. Image as data
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, including student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
Athey, Susan, and Guido W. Imbens. "Machine learning methods that economists should know about." Annual Review of Economics 11 (2019): 685-725.

Friedman, J., Hastie, T., & Tibshirani, R. (2001). The elements of statistical learning (Vol. 1, No. 10). New York: Springer series in statistics.

Mullainathan, S. and Spiess, J. (2017). Machine Learning: An Applied Econometric Approach. Journal of Economic Perspectives, 31(2):87-106
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended readings will be determined by the course instructor every year.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Machine Learning Methods for Economists
courses.description: Large-scale data set has become increasingly available in many fields of economics. This presents challenges to statistical inference and even merely “understanding” the data. Meanwhile, it offers abundant opportunities for new inquiries and answers. In this course, we introduce the core statistical methods to work with big data (structured and unstructured) and show how these techniques can be combined with econometric tools in economics research. While we cover major machine learning tools, including supervised learning methods, unsupervised learning and dimensionality reduction, we will focus on their concrete applications in current empirical research. Examples will be drawn from various lines of research, including text as data, relevant prediction problems in economics, and causal inference.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will i) understand the key ideas behind the design of machine learning algorithms, ii) understand the assumptions for each method to work, iii) learn to code simulation and statistical methods in R and/or python, and iv) identify fruitful cases to deploy Machine Learning methods and evaluate the associated merits and constraints.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: machine learning vs economics
2. Overview of machine learning in economics
3. Linear regression with many covariates
4. Penalized regression: Lasso
5. Bias/variance trade-off, regularization, cross validation
6. Trees and partitioning method
7. Ensemble
8. Neural network
9. Dimension reduction: Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and factor models
10. K-means clustering
11. Topic modeling
12. Generative language model
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, including student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
James, G., Witten, D., Hastie, T., & Tibshirani, R. (2013). An introduction to statistical learning (Vol. 112, p. 18). New York: springer.

Friedman, J., Hastie, T., & Tibshirani, R. (2001). The elements of statistical learning (Vol. 1, No. 10). New York: Springer series in statistics.

Schütze, H., Manning, C. D., & Raghavan, P. (2008). Introduction to information retrieval (Vol. 39, pp. 234-265). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended readings will be determined by the course instructor every year.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Analysis of China’s Economy
courses.description: Using the Chinese economy as a context, the course is designed to guide and train students to think courageously, creatively, and critically. Students are required to find “puzzles” in the contemporary Chinese economy, to develop economic issues of general relevance from these “puzzles”, to frame these issues into theoretical or empirical questions, and finally to draft papers based on these questions. The course relies heavily on class discussion. Students are required to present at each stage of their thinking process. Students are advised to take ECON5011, 5021 and 5121 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completing this course, students should have developed some ability in thinking creatively and critically of issues related to the Chinese economy, the culture of the Chinese society, the forces underlying Chinese economic development, and the political architecture of China. In addition, this course equips students with powerful analytical tools in interpreting complex economic phenomena. It develops skills in articulating ideas in verbal and written form through such exercises as term papers, oral presentations, and class discussions. Finally, it enhances the philosophy of life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction: First Principles and Study of the Chinese Economy

Part I: Some Basics

– Economic Growth and Human Enlightenment

– Organizing Economic Activities: Firm, Government, and Market

– First Welfare Theorem, Coase Theorem, and Role of Government

– Frictions and Industrial Policies

Part II: China’s Economic Development from the Perspective of Industrial Policies

– Catching-up, Leapfrogging, v.s. Comparative Advantages

– Institutional Arrangements Complementing Industrial Policies

– Transition: Institution Reforms

– Integrating China with the Rest of the World

– Competition for Rent and Income Inequality/Mobility

Part III: China’s Political Economy and Beyond

– Communist Party Regime as a Self-Electing Succession

– Democracy or not

– Grassroot Democracy

– Enforcement: the Chinese Style

– Tolerance and Freedom of Speech

– Sovereignty and Freedom to Move

Part IV: China’s Culture and Knowledge Development

– “Skill” versus “Tools”, Idiosyncracy versus Generality

– Implications: Human Capital Investment, Occupational Choices and the Organization of Economic

Activities, Trade and Growth

– Returns to Knowledge, “Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle”, and Implications for Policy Innovation

and Emulation

Part V: Random Topics by Students

courses.required_readings:
Robert Cooter (1989) “The Coase Theorem” in The New Palgrave: Allocation, Information, and Markets

Friedrich Hayek (1945) “The Use of Knowledge in Society” American Economic Review

Angus Maddison (1998) Chinese Economic Performance in the Long Run, Chapter 1 - 2

Yingyi Qian (2000) “The Process of China’s Market Transition (1978-98): The Evolutionary, Historical, and Comparative Perspectives” Journal of Institutional and Theoretical Economics, v156, n.1

Jiahua Che (2010): “A Road Next to Democracy: China's Communist Party regime as a self-electing succession mechanism”, working paper

Larry Lau, Yingyi Qian, and Gerald Roland (2000):“Reform without Losers: An interpretation of China's dual-track approach to transition”, Journal of Political Economy, v108, n 1

Jiahua Che and Wen Zhou (2010):“The Last Supper: Complementing Financial Discipline with Bailouts”, working paper

Chenggang Xu (2010), “The Institutional Foundations of China’s Reforms and Development”, CEPR Discussion Paper No. DP7654 Justin Lin, Fang Cai, and Li Zhou (2003): The China Miracle: Development strategy and economic reform

courses.course_syllabus:
* Topic 1: China’s National Accounts
* Topic 2: Conceptual Framework: A Model of “Crony Capitalism”
* Topic 3: Firms: The Rise of the Private Sector and the Transformation of the State Sector
* Topic 4: Government: Merit- vs. Connection-Based Evaluations and their Implications
* Topic 5: Extension of the Baseline Framework: Misallocation and Aggregate Implications
* Topic 6: Extension of the Baseline Framework: Recent Institutional Changes and Economic Slowdown
* Topic 7: Domestic Structural Issues (barriers to rural-urban migration, population ageing, underdeveloped service sector, allocative inefficiency of R&D investment …)

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Monetary Economics
courses.description: This graduate-level course studies advanced monetary economics. Its focus will be on models and theories of money and financial intermediation, but relevant empirical literature will be incorporated as well. The topics include ISLM model in open economies, OLG monetary model, flexible price monetary model, such as MIU and CIA model and new Keynesian sticky price model. China's monetary policies will also be discussed in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review on ISLM model in open economy
2. Empirical evidence and methods
3. MIU and CIA models
4. Lucas Island Model
5. Limited participation model
6. Model with Sticky Wages and Sticky Prices
7. New Keynesian Model
8. Exchange rate and monetary policy in Open Economy
9. Inflation bias and time inconsistency
10. Selected topics on China's monetary policy

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Financial Economics
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a foundation to pursue further research in the theory of financial economics. This course requires a sound understanding of microeconomic theory and an understanding and appreciation of finance problems as prerequisites. It is presumed that students are already familiar with the material at the level of Copeland and Weston (1988). It should be emphasized that research in finance requires a rigorous training in both microeconomic theory and econometrics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to gain an advanced understanding of the topics and research methodology of some major research areas in financial economics. Students will receive training in thesis and report writing. The course will prove useful in developing the student's career in financial professions.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1: Asset Pricing Theory

1. Equilibrium approach

• Utility, stochastic discount factor and asset returns

• CAPM, ICAPM and APT

• Return predictability

• Cross-section of securities return and firm characteristics

• Interest rate and discounting. Term structure

2. Relative approach

• Risk-neutral valuation

• Properties of options

• Binomial tree, continuous-time stochastic modeling and option pricing

Part 2: Market Microstructure Theory and Empirical Methods

1. Trading mechanisms: dealer markets, limit order markets and over-the-counter markets

2. Modeling asymmetric information

• Sequential trade model

• Continuous auctions

• Roll model

3. Limit order market

4. Liquidity

5. Over the counter market

6. Short-selling

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Financial Economics

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1

courses.description: This course provides the economic foundation of modern asset pricing theory. It serves as an introduction to the functioning of the financial market as an efficient venue for financing investment activities. Various issues on risk measurement, risk assessment, managing risk, investors’ psychological attitudes towards risk, and its implications on consumption and portfolio decision making in an uncertain world will be introduced and discussed. In-depth treatment will be given to the classical Markowitz’s mean-variance analysis, CAPM, multi-factor asset pricing theory and no-arbitrage asset pricing theory as cornerstones of modern finance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
The sessions outlined below include topics to be covered in this course. These are only tentative and more time will be spent on some topics than others.
1. Expected Utility and Risk Aversion

* Utility theory under uncertainty
* Absolute and relative risk aversion
* Stochastic dominance

2. Mean Variance Analysis

* Efficient frontier with N risky assets
* Efficient frontier with riskless Asset

3. Linear Factor Models

* Equilibrium CAPM
* Multi-factor asset pricing theory

4. No-Arbitrage Asset Pricing Theory with Applications

* Introduction to Derivatives
* Pricing Forwards and Futures
* Option Pricing: put-call parity, Binomial Option Pricing, Black-Scholes Model
* Credit Risk Modeling

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Public Economics
courses.description: This course discusses the theory and practice of public finance, focusing on the quantitative effects of public policies. There are two parts in this course – government spending and government revenue (taxes). The course emphasizes on the experience of United States public finance; students will be trained to use sophisticated cross-section and panel data and SAS/STATA programming techniques will be taught extensively throughout the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students should:

1. Have a comprehensive understanding of the components of the government budget that affect individual welfare

2. Have ideas as to how government spending programs may generate unintended consequences and what research techniques should be used to quantitatively analyze their impacts.

3. Be able to handle large-scale microeconomic data with modern econometric softwares.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Trade
courses.description: This course offers theoretical, empirical and current topics in international trade. It covers studies of positive issues, such as: Why do countries trade? What goods do countries trade? How does openness to trade shape countries' industrial structure and global production sharing? The course also concerns the normative issues, such as: Is trade beneficial to everyone, or are there winners and losers? What is the impact of trade on economic growth, wage inequality and poverty? All these issues will be discussed both from theories and empirics, as well as at country, industry and firm level. In particular, we will also discuss the ongoing US-China trade war.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture Outlines: (11 weeks)
Section I: Neoclassical Theories of Trade (4 weeks)
1. Introduction (0.5 week)
2. Ricardian Model (0.5 week)
3. The Heckscher-Ohlin Model (Feenstra, Ch 1-2) (1.5 weeks)
4. Trade in intermediate goods and wage inequality (Feenstra, Olin-lecture) (1.5 weeks)

Section II: “New” and “New New” Trade Theory (6 weeks)
5. Increasing Returns and the Gravity Equation-Krugman model (1 week)
6. New Economic Geography (0.5 week)
7. Heterogeneous firms-Melitz model (2003) (2.5 weeks)
8. Eaton and Kortum (2002) framework (2 weeks) Section III: The US-China Trade War (1 week)
9. The US-China Trade War: the causes and consequences

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Finance
courses.description: This course is a graduate-level course of international finance. It will cover some recent topics on current account dynamics, real business cycle, exchange rate and international monetary policy. We will be focusing on the basic implications of the theory and empirical support for the theories. In addition, we will be discussing the experience of currency and capital market crises and the evolution of global imbalances in the last decade.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completing this course, the student should 1) have some ideas about the key topics in international finance, such as current account and exchange rate; 2) be able to analyze the real issues of international finance using the models taught in class.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to International Finance (ISLM model)
2. International Capital Markets and the Current Account. (OR Chapter 1, 2, 3).
3. The Real Exchange Rate (OR Chapter 4)
4. RBC in Small Open Economies (notes)
5. China in the Global Economy (papers)
All students are expected to read and understand The Chinese University of Hong Kong's policies with regard to academic dishonesty. These policies are available at the following web addresses:
http://www.cuhk.edu.hk/policy/academichonesty/.
With each assignment, students will be required to submit a statement that they are aware of these policy, regulations, guidelines and procedures.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Finance
courses.description: This is a graduate-level international finance course. It aims to provide students with a solid understanding of the modern theories and empirics of international finance. Topics covered in this course include: exchange rate determination theories, exchange rate regimes, capital flows, currency crises, international monetary policy spillovers and coordination, among others.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Development Economics
courses.description: This course explores the framework and analytical methods that are commonly used in applied economic research, drawing most examples from development economics, growth analysis, and labor economics. The main objective is to examine how analytical tools of economics can be applied in studying simple models of individual, household, and market behaviors. Conceptual and empirical research will receive approximately the same class time. Special applications are made to the Chinese and East Asian economies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students should have acquired:
• basic knowledge about constructing economic models and in applying those models to analyze individual, family, and market behavior
• specific skills of conducting empirical economic research, such as securing data sources, measurement, econometric specifications and hypothesis testing
• knowledge on the Chinese and Asia-Pacific economies.

courses.required_readings:

II. Labor Supply and Household Production Models

A. Theoretical background
Silberberg, Eugene Wing Suen, Wing. “The Labor-Leisure Choice,” In The Structure of Economics: A Mathematical Analysis, Third Edition, Boston: McGraw Hill (2001): pp 299-304 (handouts).

III. Human Capital and Technical Change

A. Theoretical background

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Development Economics
courses.description: The goal of this course is to understand the economic problems of developing countries by using economic theories and their applications. The course will cover both macroeconomic and microeconomic approaches to development economics. We will first overview the theories of growth and discuss their potential in explaining income differences across countries, and then study the different facets of human development: market, institution, and culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introduction: Global Patterns of Economic Growth and Development
* Growth theory I: Classical Growth Theories
* Growth theory II: Complementarity
* Inequality and Social Mobility
* Market I: Land Market
* Market II: Labor Market
* Market III: Credit Market
* Institution and Comparative Development
* Culture I: The Effects of Culture
* Culture II: Culture Formation
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Labour Economics
courses.description: The course provides a theoretical and empirical foundation for the analysis of labor market. Topics to be covered include: labor supply and demand, minimum wages, migration, human capital and education production, labor market incentives, efficiency wage, and skill investment. Students should preferably have finished graduate level Microeconomic theory and Econometric Theory and Application before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, students should have a good understanding of the theories and empirical strategies used in labour economics, develop their own research interests, and be able to apply the theories and empirical strategies learned in the course to conduct their independent research.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Empirical Strategies in Labor Economics
II. Neoclassical Labor Supply Model
III. Labor Demand, Minimum Wage, and Immigration
IV. Human Capital and Education
V. Investment in Skills
VI. Incentives, Agency, and Efficiency Wage
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation on the scope of the course, well-preparedness of the teaching staff, ability of the teaching staff to inspire students, mode of assessment, and others, will be submitted by students after completing the course.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Corporate Finance
courses.description:
This course addresses the economic theory and empirics of corporate finance and governance. The goal is to help students understand major research issues in the field and develop their skills to apply theory to corporate finance practices. It focuses on important topics such as capital structure, ownership structure, capital budgeting and corporate governance institutions. The course extensively uses the tools of game theory, information economics and microeconometrics.
Students are recommended to take ECON 5011 and ECON 5121 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics or Local/ Offshore MSc Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to gain an advanced understanding of the topics and research methodology of some major research areas in corporate finance. Students will receive training in thesis and report writing. Upon completing this course, the student’s preparation for diverse careers in finance will be enhanced.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: an overview of corporate finance

a. Objective of a firm

b. Three building blocks: investment decision, financing decision and payout decision

c. Managerial incentives

2. Investment decision

a. Background material

i. Financial statements and cash flows

ii. Time value of money

b. Bond valuation and stock valuation

c. Risk and return

i. Valuing financial assets: CAPM, APT

ii. Valuing real assets

d. Capital investment decision and capital budgeting

3. Financing decision

a. Some facts from institutional perspective

b. Basic concepts of capital structure

c. Cost of capital

d. Miller-Modigliani Theorem

e. Limits to the use of debt

f. Capital structure and corporate strategy

4. Payout decision

a. Facts about dividend policy

b. Revisiting Miller-Modigliani theorem

c. Assessing dividend policy

5. Other topics

a. Incentives and corporate control

b. Mergers and acquisitions

c. Types of acquisitions

d. Sources of takeover gains and empirical evidence

e. Bidding and defense strategies
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, Informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, Student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings: Tirole, Jean. The Theory of Corporate Finance. 2005. Princeton University Press.
courses.recommended_readings: Additional articles will be assigned by the course instructor throughout the course.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Behavioral Economics and Finance
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the theory and empirics of behavioral economics and behavioral finance. In this course, classical assumptions on economic agents such as rationality and time consistency are relaxed, allowing students to analyze investors and financial markets from a non-traditional perspective. The course is therefore a good complement to the mainstream economic and financial theories built upon individual rationality.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking the course, students should be able to apply the insights and methods learnt from the course to their research in various fields and broaden their view of various fields in economics and finance.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Behavioral economics
(1) Reference-Dependent Preference and Prospect Theory
(2) Ambiguity Aversion and Subjective Probability
(3) Gambler’s Fallacy, Hot-Hand Fallacy and the Law of Small Numbers
(4) Time-Inconsistency
(5) Overconfidence
(6) Social Preference
(7) Rationality and Decision Consistency

II. Behavioral Finance
(8) Bias of judgement and its implications for finance
(9) Frame dependence, prospect theory and finance
(10) Imperfect markets and limits of arbitrage
(11) Style investing
(12) Stock valuation
(13) Portfolio construction and risk management
(14) Asset allocation
(15) Behavioral corporate finance
(16) The indicators
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels. Student consultation during annual departmental retreat.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Behavioral Economics and Finance
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the theory and empirics of behavioral economics and behavioral finance. In this course, classical assumptions on economic agents such as rationality and time consistency are relaxed, allowing students to analyze investors and financial markets from a non-traditional perspective. The course is therefore a good complement to the mainstream economic and financial theories built upon individual rationality.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: After taking the course, students should be able to apply the insights and methods learnt from the course to their research in various fields and broaden their view of various fields in economics and finance.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *I. Behavioral Economics**

* Reference-Dependent Preference and Prospect Theory
* Ambiguity Aversion and Subjective Probability
* Gambler's Fallacy, Hot-Hand Fallacy and the Law of Small Numbers
* Time-Inconsistency
* Overconfidence
* Social Preference
* Rationality and Decision Consistency

* *II. Behavioral Finance**

* Bias of Judgement and its Implications for Finance
* Frame Dependence, Prospect Theory and Finance
* Imperfect Markets and Limits of Arbitrage
* Style Investing
* Stock Valuation
* Portfolio Construction and Risk Management
* Asset Allocation
* Behavioral Corporate Finance
* The Indicators
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Econometric Methods for Policy Evaluation
courses.description: This course is an introduction to rigorous and policy‐relevant impact evaluation strategies and techniques for postgraduate students in economics. The course's main emphasis is on empirical strategies to identify the causal effects of public policies and programs. The course has a strong focus on applications, although students will be expected to fully understand the conceptual underpinnings of each strategy. Topics include instrumental variables, fixed effects, differences-in-differences, experiments, and regression discontinuity design for policy evaluation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of the course, students will:
1. Understand the rationale of major program evaluation strategies.
2. Understand empirical studies on policy evaluation and critically assess the validity of causal claims therein.
3. Be able to determine the strengths and weaknesses of different strategies for policy evaluation.
4. Be equipped to apply those strategies in a real‐world setting with available data.
5. Be able to use a statistical package to conduct quantitative policy analysis.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Regression Control and Measurement Error

2. Instrumental Variables

3. Fixed Effects

4. Differences in Differences

5. Experiments

6. Regression Discontinuity Design

7. Experimental vs. non-experimental evaluation

8. Regression vs. Matching
courses.feedback_evaluation: Online surveys
courses.required_readings: J.D. Angrist and J.S. Pischke, Mostly Harmless Econometrics: An Empiricist's Companion, Princeton University Press, 2009

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Health Economics
courses.description: In many countries, health care spending grows much faster than GDP. Countries like the Unites States spend about 20 percent of its GDP on health care. As one of the most important “goods”, how health care is financed and delivered has large welfare implications. In this course, we will apply methods and reasoning from microeconomics to the health care sector. In particular, we will investigate different aspects of the health care system and assess how various policies affect the functioning of the health care system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Economics or MSc in Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:
• Possess a deep understanding of the key institutional details and functioning of different aspects of the health care system.
• Master the main microeconomic theory and economic techniques to analyze the major issues of the health care sector.
• Be able to critically make assessments of health economic studies and health intervention or programs.
• Have developed the ability to communicate health economic research findings to policymakers.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Demand for Health and Health Care
2. Demand for Insurance
3. Adverse Selection
4. Moral Hazard
5. Delivery of Health Care
6. Why are Costs so High?
7. Pharmaceutical Markets and Innovation
8. International Health Care Systems
9. Health Economics and Policy
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Mid-course evaluation questionnaire

End of course evaluation questionnaire

Students are also welcome to give feedback to the course at any time.
courses.required_readings: Bhattacharya, J., T. Hyde, and P. Tu (2014), Health Economics, Palgrave MacMillan, New York, USA.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Analysis of Fiscal and Monetary Policy in China
courses.description: This graduate course includes two parts. The first part provides elementary theories of monetary policy and fiscal policy, providing students a general framework for policy analysis. The second part mainly discusses the development of Chinese monetary policy and fiscal policy in the past three decades, the potential policy reform and its implications to the Chinese economy. In addition, how monetary policy and fiscal policy respond to financial crises or public health crises will be widely analyzed and discussed in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students are expected to:

* Understand the development and major issues of Chinese monetary policy and fiscal policy.
* Be able to apply the theories and methods learnt from the course to analyze Chinese monetary policy and fiscal policy, and their implications to the Chinese economy.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics covered in this course are listed below:

* Review on monetary policy and fiscal policy in the ISLM model
* Empirical evidence and methods on money, inflation and output
* Introduction to MIU, CIA and Lucas monetary models
* Introduction to the theory of public economics
* The development of monetary policy in China
* The development of fiscal policy in China
* Crisis and policy reform
* Selected topics on Chinese monetary and fiscal policy
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes
courses.recommended_readings:
* Intermediate Public Economics, by Myles, G.D. and J. Hindriks, Cambridge: MIT Press.
* Monetary Theory and Policy, by Carl E. Walsh, Fourth Edition, Cambridge: MIT Press.
* The Chinese Economy: Transitions and Growth, by Barry J. Naughton, Cambridge: MIT Press.
* Public Speech on China's Monetary Policy Framework, by Mr Yi Gang, 2018.
* China’s Monetary Policy Communication: Frameworks, Impact, and Recommendations, by Michael McMahon, Alfred Schipke and Xiang Li, IMF working paper 244, 2018.
* 2019 Article IV Consultation with the People’s Republic of China, IMF Country Report No. 266, 2019.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economic Analysis of Public Policy in China
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to contemporary public policies in China. These include economic public policies such as labor, trade, tax and poverty alleviation, as well as social public policies such as environment, population, education, healthcare and social security. This course focuses on using economic concepts and theories to analyze and evaluate such policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Part 1: Public Policies in China**

1. Institutional contexts
2. Policy making process

* *Part 2: Economic Public Policies**

1. Labor
2. Trade
3. Tax
4. Poverty

* *Part 3: Social Public Policies**

1. Environment
2. Population
3. Education
4. Healthcare
5. Social security
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.

* Barry Naughton (2018) The Chinese Economy: Adaptation and Growth, 2nd Edition, The MIT Press.
* David L. Weimer and Aidan R. Vining (2017) Policy Analysis: Concepts and Practice, 6th Edition, Longman.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Anthony Boardman, David Greenberg, Aidan Vining, and David Weimer (2018) Cost-Benefit Analysis: Concepts and Practice, 5th Edition. Prentice-Hall.
* Arthur R. Kroeber (2020) China’s Economy: What Everyone Needs to Know, 2nd Edition, Oxford University Press.
* Christoph Knill and Jale Tosun (2020) Public Policy: A New Introduction, 2nd Edition, Red Globe Press.
* Eugene S. Bardach and Eric M. Patashnik (2019) A Practical Guide for Policy Analysis: The Eightfold Path to More Effective Problem Solving, 6th Edition, CQ Press.
* Jonathan Gruber (2019) Public Finance and Public Policy, 6th Edition, Worth Publishers.
* Roger Miller, Daniel Benjamin, and Douglas North (2017) The Economics of Public Issues, 20th Edition, Addison-Wesley.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Global Economics and Finance Forum
courses.description:
This course is designed to enhance students’ exposure to and understanding of a wide variety of real world economic and financial issues in Hong Kong, Mainland China, and the world to strengthen their ability to analyze policy issues.

Distinguished economists, business leaders, and/or government officials will be invited to deliver lectures on a wide range of leading economic and financial issues in the global economy. Through these lectures, students are trained to strengthen their capability of conducting innovative analyses of these issues with significant policy implications.

Students are required to write research papers for the course. The papers demonstrate students’ own analyses and understanding of the course content.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Economics, MPhil Economics, MSc Economics or MSc Applied Economics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to gain an advanced understanding of some leading issues in the global economy and finance and have a firm grasp of some basic research methodology in economics and finance. Students will receive training in application of economic theory to analyze policy issues. The course aims at improving students’ preparation for their career development in business and financial positions as well as further academic studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Theory: International Finance, International Trade, and Economic Development
* Rise of China and the World Economy
* Topics on current global economics issues by Guest Speakers
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey conducted by Department, informal feedback from students via diverse communication channels, student consultation during annual departmental retreat.
courses.required_readings:
* Krugman, Paul R., Obstfeld, Maurice, and Melitz, Marc J., 2012, International Economics: Theory and Policy, Pearson International Edition, 9th Edition.
* Naughton, Barry, 2018. The Chinese Economy: Adaptation and Growth, 2nd Edition, The MIT Press.
* Kroeber, Arthur R., 2016, China’s Economy: What Everyone Needs to Know, Oxford University Press.
* Economy, Elizabeth C, 2018. The Third Revolution: Xi Jinping and the new Chinese state, Oxford University Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
* Feenstra, Robert C. and Taylor, Alan M., International Economics, Worth Publishers, 2012.
* Lardy, Nicholas, 2018. The State Strikes Back: The End of Economic Reform in China, Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington D.C.
* Bergsten Fred C. et. al., 2009. China’s Rise: Challenges and Opportunities, Peterson. Institute for International Economics and Center for Strategic and International Studies, Washington D.C.
